She is 31 years old, in a common law marriage, and has a 9 year old child. Gina and her husband work together at an auto repair shop. She helps her husband with various duties that need to be performed in their business. Gina is requesting a loan to invest in her home and make a few improvements a little bit at a time.

She is happy with the loan that was provided and promises to complete her payments on time.

loans.use: Home improvements

loans.name: Zayat

texts.en: Zayat, 48, is widowed and lives with her son in Bayanhongor province of Mongolia. They live in a ger, a Mongolian nomadic housing tent.  Her son currently works in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. She began sewing clothes in 1981 and worked for a few small companies that made and repaired clothes. She began operating her own clothing making business in 2006.  She wants to expand her business and open her own small factory in the future. She is a hardworking person who says, " I want to work with other tailors and operate a small clothing factory." She is requesting a loan of 550,000 MNT to purchase textile and cloth for her business.

loans.use: To purchase textile and cloth

loans.name: Aisha

texts.en:
Aisha S. is married but has no children. She lives in a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food.

For the past three years, Aisha has operated a food stall from her home. She sells her goods to neighbors and passersby. Aisha’s major challenge is seasonality in her business.

With a loan of 20,000 KES she wants to purchase cooking oil, potatoes and sacks of charcoal to sell. Aisha dreams of expanding her business in the future.

loans.use: To purchase cooking oil, potatoes and sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Abdul

texts.en:
This is 25-year-old Abdul S. K.. He is married, and has two children aged two and four years. He is very serious and dedicated.

In 2009, Abdul established his stationery business. Working six days a week and ten hours a day, he earns about 500,000 SLL every month.

Abdul would like a loan in the amount of 3,000,000 SLL to buy business stock such as cartons of ledger books, duplicating papers and exercise books. He hopes that this loan will enable him to increase his monthly profits by approximately 100,000 SLL.

In the future, Abdul plans to educate his children to university level, construct a house and buy a car. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy cartons of ledger books, duplicating papers and exercise books

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan C. is currently in the business of selling charcoal. She is 30 years old, married and has three children. Two of them go to school. 

Susan borrowed a loan to stock more charcoal to sell. She hopes to expand her business in the future with extra profits from her loan.

loans.use: to stock more charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose currently sells beans.  She is 25 years old and single. Rose  requested a loan to stock more beans to sell.  She hopes to build a big shop in the future with extra profits from her business.

loans.use: to stock more beans to sell.

loans.name: Sally

texts.en:
Sally is an entrepreneur from the town of Banga, South Cotabato. She is engaged in farming and an eatery business. She primarily grows corn crops to sell. She also cooks the food that she sells at her eatery.

Sally needs fertilizers and raw ingredients like vegetables and oil, for cooking viands to sell at her eatery. She requested a loan to fund her businesses. She will also buy soft drinks for her eatery. Sally works hard to improve her businesses and her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and raw ingredients such as vegetables and oil, and also soft drinks.

loans.name: Luis Alfonso

texts.es: Luis  de 50 años, residente en Soledad en compañía de su cónyuge y sus dos hijos en las edades de 9 y 13 años, es el propietario del negocio “Tienda El Patrón” experiencia que surgió hace muchos años cuando necesitó ayudar a su madre, así fue que recurrió primero a préstamos informales de alto costo, pero gradualmente cuando fue saliendo de estas deudas empezó a generar más utilidades y su negocio le entusiasmó, pero continuó trabajando con préstamos de proveedores a 30 días, Hoy quiere buscar mejores opciones en compras de contado y esta es la razón por la cual acude a su credikiva que es el primer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo con el cual comprará ranchos víveres, bebidas, dulces y enlatados en mayor proporción y de contado, lo cual le augura muy buenos descuentos con los que alcanzará a generar mayores utilidades sobre sus ventas. Su sueño más adelante es tener una casa propia con su local para poner su tienda,por eso mientras trabaja para lograrlo continua esforzándose por aumentar sus utilidades, que se encuentran en un porcentaje no menor a un 30%, y sigue manejando sus ventas de contado y tambien con mucha prudencia los pocos créditos que hace a sus mejores clientes.
texts.en:
Luis, 50, lives in Soledad with his spouse and two children who are 9 and 13 years old.  He owns a store called “Tienda El Patrón” that arose years ago when he needed to help his mother.  This is how he first called upon informal, high cost loans but as he gradually came out from under these debts he started to generate more profits and his business excited him.  He continued to work with 30 day loan providers, however.  

Today, he wants to find better options for making cash purchases and this is why he’s called on his Kiva loan which is the first loan he’s made with Fundación Mario Santo Domingo and that he’ll use to buy snacks, foodstuffs, beverages, candy and canned goods in larger amounts and paying cash which will insure better discounts that will lead to better profits on sales.

His dream for later on is to have a house of his own with space to install the store.  For this reason, while he works to reach it he continues to try to increase his profits which currently are no less than 30% and he continues to handle cash sales and exercise much prudence with the few loans he extends to his best customers.

loans.use: to buy snacks, foodstuffs, beverages, candy and canned goods in larger amounts and paying cash.

loans.name: Mohamed

texts.fr:
Mohamed est un homme âgé de 28 ans. Il est marié å une revendeuse.
Mohamed a travaillé comme revendeur depuis 2007. Il vend des matériels d'électricité. Il achète les produits au Grand Marché de Lomé. 
Mohamed a requis son premier crédit de WAGES afin d’acheter 2 douzaines de disjoncteurs originaux, 5 cartons d'ampoules ordinaires et 2 rouleaux de fil.
texts.en: Mohamed is a 28-year-old man. His wife is a retailer. Mohamed, too, has been a retailer since 2007. He sells electrical equipment. He gets his supplies at the Great Market in Lomé. Mohamed came to the microfinance institution WAGES and applied for his first loan to buy 2 dozens of original circuit-breakers, 5 boxes of standard bulbs and 2 rolls of cord.

loans.use: to buy electrical equipment.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy blasting materials and to employ two more people.

loans.name: Sambi Ternak Group

texts.en: Like many Balinese women, Luh and the other members of the Sambi Ternak group raise pigs in their yards to supplement their families’ incomes.  Though many women support their families in this way, they may not know the best way to raise pigs to maximize income. Luh hopes that, through the MUK Pig Breeder Loan program, she will not only get capital but will also get training from MUK on the best way to feed and care for pigs. Luh will use her share of the loan to purchase piglets and pig feed.  She plans to sell the piglets after six months to use as pork.  With her profits, she will help support her family of three by supplementing the income of her husband.  Ultimately, Luh hopes that the increased income will enable her to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: To purchase piglets and pig feed

loans.name: Tomasa Yamilet

texts.es: En el departamento de Somotillo conocimos a la señora Tomasa de 31 años es madre soltera con 2 hijos a su cargo. Ella para ganarse algo propio y sentirse útil se dedica a la venta de ropa, su forma de venta es de manera ambulante ya que así realiza gran parte de sus ventas. Trabaja todos los días, deja a crédito sus mejores clientes y cobra cada quince días. Su mercadería la tiene que buscar en el mercado de Managua donde obtiene estos productos mucho más favorables. Este crédito lo va a emplear en comprar pantalones, camisas, faldas, trajes y vestidos. Su sueño es tener una distribuidora de ropa o una boutique.
texts.en: We met Tomasa, 31, in Somotillo Department.  She’s a single mother of two children in her care.  To earn a bit for herself and to feel useful she’s a street vendor of clothes; this is how most of her sales take place.  She works every day and sells to her best customers on credit; she collects every two weeks.  She gets her merchandise in Managua’s market where she finds the most affordable prices.  She will use this loan to buy pants, shirts, skirts, suits and dresses.  Her dream is to be a clothing supplier or to have a boutique.

loans.use: to buy clothes.

loans.name: Herminio

texts.en:
Herminio is a local farmer living in Dalaoig, Alcala, Cagayan. To generate income and provide sustenance for the family, Herminio devotes himself full-time to sowing, planting, and harvesting rice from his half-hectare of farmland. He has been engaged in this business for three years. 

He wakes up early and immediately goes to the rice field, a 10-minute walk along his house. When he harvests his crop, Herminio sells the produce to traders. Income generated from the business, amounting to P 25,000, is generally spent on school fees and household expenses such as food and electric bills. Herminio's spouse works as a housekeeper and takes care of their three children. 

Herminio is requesting a loan of P11,000 to buy seeds and fertilizers and to pay for labor costs for land cultivation and the transplanting of rice seedlings. He is confident that the help of this loan will help his operation improve crop production.

In the future, Herminio would like to earn consistent profits so that he can save for future emergencies.

loans.use: to pay for labor costs for land cultivation and the transplanting of rice seedlings

loans.name: Shiella Mae

texts.en:
For the past six years Shiella Mae, a 22-year-old married resident of Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur, Philippines, has raised a variety of of fish to sell in the town market and on an individual order basis. Along with other irregular sources of income, she earns PHP 15,000 a month.

Shiella Mae is receiving her first loan of PHP 30,000 from GDMPC to expand her production of fish. This year she expects to reap a good harvest and obtain a very favorable price for her fish. Profits will be used to buy more fish and feed.

loans.use: to expand fish production.

loans.name: Tepepa Group

texts.es:
La señora Martina acaba de iniciar su negocio de tienda de abarrotes, con el primer crédito que acaba de otorgar Fundación Realidad, esta señora trabaja en su casa pero además le ayuda su esposo quien sale a vender la mercancía en otros pueblitos.
Ella forma parte del grupo Tepepa (piedras encimadas en náhuatl) cuyos  integrantes  además de la señora Martina son:
•	Francisco-venta  de leña
•	Tomas-tienda de abarrotes
•	Juventino y su hijo Silvino unieron su crédito para poner una tienda de abarrotes
Este es el primer crédito que FRAC  da en esta región, además es un crédito especial que da una tasa de interés mas baja de lo normal además de capacitación
texts.en:
Martina just started her grocery store with the first loan awarded by Fundación Realidad.  She works at home, but her husband helps her by going to other towns to sell the merchandise.

Martina is part of Tepepa Group ("tepepa" means "stacked rocks" in Nahuatl).  The other members are Francisco, who sells firewood; Tomás, who has a grocery store; and Juventino and his son Silvino, who combined their loans to start a grocery store.

This is the first FRAC loan in this region.  In addition, it is a special loan that offers a lower-than-normal interest rate as well as training.

loans.use: to buy oil, soap, beans, and soft drinks.

loans.name: Tirisa

texts.en:
Tirisa is 49 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married and has five children. 

Tirisa has a shop that sells canned goods, snacks and beverages. She has had this business for two years. 

She requested a loan for PHP 7,000 to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages.

Tirisa has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Tirisa hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages.

loans.name: Svetlana

texts.ru:
Светлана начала свой бизнес по продаже одежды 15 лет назад. Благодаря своему трудолюбию и настойчивости, а также заинтересованности в работе с данной группой товаров, она смогла сделать свой бизнес стабильным и успешным. На данный момент Светлана работает на местном Рижском рынке в городе Мелитополе, где она проживает вместе со своей семьей. Ее оборотный капитал составляет 40 000 гривен. 

Светлане необходим кредит в размере 12 000 гривен для того, чтобы закупить женскую одежду к осеннему сезону. Светлана надеется увеличить ассортимент продаваемого товара и продажи, а, значит, получить дополнительную прибыль. За счет получения дополнительной прибыли клиент будет улучшать благосостояние своей семьи. 

Пометка: история на РУССКОМ языке
texts.en:
Svetlana started her business selling clothing fifteen years ago. Svetalna is hardworking and persistent as well as very interested in working with the given niche of merchandise and thanks to that she was able to create a stable and successful business. At this time Svetlana works on the local market called Rijskiy in the town of Melitopol where she lives with her family. Her working capital is 40,000 hrivna.

Svetlana needs a loan in the amount of 12,000 hrivna to buy women's clothing for the autumn season. Svetlana hopes to increase the variety of her merchandise and also sales as well as get additional profit. By getting that profit she will improve the well being of her family.

loans.use: to purchase women's clothing for the autumn season

loans.name: Margarita

texts.es: Margarita, de 38 años, es una mujer sencilla y muy responsable, es muy valiente pues tiene la fuerza para poder seguir con su vida hacia delante aún siendo madre soltera. Ella tiene tres hijos de 19, 13 y 12 años, quienes dependen de ella para su educación y alimentación, vive en casa de sus padres junto a ellos y cuatro personas más, entre ellos sus hermanos y algunos sobrinos. El trabajo de Margarita consiste en la venta de comida, ella inicia sus labores muy temprano, sale en busca de sus productos frescos y saludable, de ahí se dirige a su casa para iniciar con la elaboración de sus platillos. A las 5 de la tarde empieza la venta, colocando la parrilla, para que de una vez se vayan asando los alimentos que preparó. Su puesto esta cerca de la municipalidad de Manantay, y lleva haciendo este trabajo por un año aproximadamente, asimismo recibe la ayuda de su hermana y juntas hacen que su trabajo sea muy entretenido. Todo le gusta de su trabajo ya que le encanta cocinar, estar en contacto con los clientes, pues ellos la consideran buena cocinera y además brinda un buen servicio. Espera mas adelante colocar mesas y sillas para ofrecer mayor comodidad a sus hijos. Este será el tercer crédito con la institución, le esta yendo bien y esta contenta de pertenecer a su grupo ya que hasta el momento todos se mostraron como personas responsables. Agradece también  a todos sus ustedes por su apoyo anteriormente, por lo que espera nuevamente su ayuda. Con el monto solicitado, comprará mesas, sillas, cubiertos, y algunas cosas más para implementar su puesto de comida.
texts.en:
Margarita is 38 years old. She is a sincere and responsible person, brave with the strength to improve her life, although being a single mother. She has three children who are 19, 13, and 12 years old who depend on her for their food and education. She lives with her parents in their house together with four more people including her siblings and some nieces and nephews. Margarita sells food. She begins work very early leaving in search of fresh and healthy food and from there she continues back to her house to begin the preparation of her food courses.

At five o’clock in the afternoon she begins her sales, putting out the grill, so they can roast the prepared food. She is located in the town of Montara Ray, and has been doing this work for about a year. Her sister helps her and together they enjoy their work very much. She likes everything about her work. She loves to cook. She likes serving her clients and they consider her a good cook, and she likes to give good customer service.

She wants to buy, at a later date, chairs and tables in order to provide more comfort for her children. This will be her third loan with this communal bank. Everything is going well and she is happy to belong to her group and everybody has shown themselves to be responsible members. She is also very grateful to all of you for your help in the past and she hopes you can help her again. She plans to buy tables, chairs and cutlery and some other things in order to prepare her food.

loans.use: to buy tables and chairs

loans.name: Ailyn

texts.en:
As a married parent of 2 children, Ailyn works hard to support her family.

She has a banana retail business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from ice cream vending. Ailyn is borrowing PHP 24,000 through NWTF to purchase additional stock of bananas to sell in her business.

Ailyn has been sustaining her business activities through her past 10 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock of bananas to sell

loans.name: Jackline

texts.en:
Jackline is 32 years old and lives in the town of Masindi in Uganda. She is widowed and has four children with three of them currently in school. For the past three years, Jackline has been working hard to manage her small shop, which sells ladies' cosmetics. 

To help expand her business, Jackline has requested a loan of 3,000,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase new and different cosmetic products, and it will help Jackline to generate greater profits and build her own house. Jackline hopes that in the future her shop will become the leading wholesale business for cosmetics in all of Masindi. 

Jackline is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Jackline who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase new and different cosmetic products.

loans.name: Jessica

texts.en:
Jessica is 30 years old and is a married woman with 5 children. The oldest child is 12 years old. Her husband works as a carpenter and seaweed gatherer.

Jessica has been engaged in seaweed farming for 5 years. She earns 10,000 PHP per month doing this farming. Jessica plans to use her loan to purchase seaweed seedlings, straw and wooden pegs. Jessica hopes to have a stable income to support her family.

loans.use: to purchase seaweed seedlings, straw and wooden pegs

loans.name: Alida

texts.es:
Alida es socia del Banco Comunal “Brisas del Lago”  ubicado en el distrito,  provincia y departamento de Puno, tiene 37 años de edad, está casada y tiene dos hijos.  Cuenta con estudios de educación superior.

Desde hace tres años trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos, su primer préstamo fue de S/. 300.00 nuevo soles, dinero que incrementó al capital de su negocio de venta de artículos artesanales y venta de comidas.  Actualmente se dedica a la venta de materiales de construcción (ladrillos). 

Solicitará un nuevo crédito por la suma de S/. 3000.00 nuevo soles, préstamo que invertirá en la compra de cinco millares de ladrillos panderetas y ladrillos mecanizadas. En el negocio trabaja junto con su hermano, su esposo trabaja en la ciudad de Tacna.

La señora desea tener un negocio de servicio de internet ya que genera buenas ganancias.
 
Lo que más le gusta de su Banco Comunal es la facilidad del préstamo.
texts.en:
Alida is a member of the “Brisas del Lago” (Lake Breezes) communal bank in the district, province and department of Puno.  She is 37 years old, married, and has two children.  She has a post high school education.

She has worked with the Movimiento Manuela Ramos for three years.  She used her first loan for 300 soles to increase the capital in her business of selling handicrafts and food.  She currently sells construction materials (bricks).

She is requesting a new loan for 3,000 soles.  She will use the loan to buy five thousand bricks for walls and machine made bricks.  She works with her brother in the business.  He husband works in the city of Tacna.

She wishes to have an internet service business because it generates good income.

What she likes best about her communal bank are the easy terms of the loan.

loans.use: to buy five thousand bricks for walls and machine made bricks.

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce is a hardworking woman who is in the business of selling water. She has been doing this for the last five years and has been able to support her family with her business. Jane was introduced to KADET by an existing women's group in her area. She has been a good client who has repaid her previous loans without delay. 

Jane is requesting her third loan that she will use to buy more pumps to aid in water distribution. She hopes to save her profit to invest in buying a second-hand pickup truck to distribute water. Jane dreams of being very rich and financially stable in future.

loans.use: to buy water distribution pumps

loans.name: Consuelo

texts.en:
Consuelo is separated from her husband, and has 5 children. She is 43 years old and lives in La Esperanza, Rizal.  Consuelo sells bread to earn a living and has had this business for 6 years. She has requested a loan of 20,000 to purchase raw ingredients to make a product to sell.
Consuelo has been a member of PMPC for less than a year.

loans.use: To purchase 10 sacks of flour and other ingredients for bread-making

loans.name: Boniface

texts.en:
Boniface is 41 years old, married to Lucy and they are blessed with one child.  He has been in the mixed crop farming business for the past twenty years with a monthly income of KES 8,000 which he uses to support his family.

He is applying for his first loan of KES 15,000 with KADET after being introduced by an existing KADET customer.  Boniface will use the loan to buy seedlings and fertilizer for his farm.  With the anticipated profit from the business he will educate his child. 

His hopes and dreams are to venture into pig rearing and diversify his income, which will help him improve the living standard of his family.

loans.use: to buy seedlings and fertilizer for his farm.

loans.name: Akouegnon 10 Group

texts.fr: Le groupe AKOUEGNON 10 est composé de trois personnes qui sont des amies et résident dans le même quartier. La représentante du groupe, du nom de Gbèssito Odile est celle qui a la main levée sur la photo. Gbèssito Odile est âgée de 28 ans et vit au Bénin. Gbèssito Odile a arrêté l’école au niveau secondaire. Gbèssito Odile est mariée à un certain Galbert. Le couple a deux enfants tous scolarisés et à leur charge. Gbèssito Odile vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants.  Le couple assure ensemble les diverses charges de la maison. Afin d'assurer les diverses charges de la famille, Gbèssito Odile vend depuis quatre ans, divers produits (conserves, pâtes alimentaires) à son domicile. De façon secondaire, Gbèssito Odile vend de l'eau fraîche et des jus de bissape. Gbèssito Odile s'approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle et pour accroître son chiffre d’affaires et son revenu, Gbèssito Odile sollicite ensemble avec les autres membres du groupe AKOUEGNON 10, un crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Group Akouegnon 10 is composed of three friends who reside in the same area of town. The group's representative, named Gbèssito Odile, is the woman raising her hand on the photo.
Gbèssito Odile is 28 years old and lives in Benin. Her education stopped in middle school. Gbèssito Odile is married to Galbert. The couple has two children, who both attend school and are in their care. Gbèssito Odile lives together with her husband and children. The couple provides for the household together.
In order to support her family, Gbèssito Odile has been selling various products (canned food, pasta) from her home for four years. As a side activity, she sells fresh water and hibiscus flower tea. She gets her supplies from a market in Benin. Looking to increase customer satisfaction, sales, and revenues, Gbèssito Odile and the other members of group Akouegnon 10 are requesting a loan from ALIDé.

loans.use: to buy various products (canned food, peas, rices).

loans.name: Zainab's Group

texts.en:
Zainab is a member of this group from Iraq. Zainab is 45 years old divorced and has three child . Zainab started her sewing business fourteen years ago with an old sewing machine to generate enough income to support herself and her children.
She is requesting this (Qard Hassan ) loan that Izdiharona provide for divorced and widow women to buy an air-conditioner  and over sewing machine  to help her increase her income.
She aims to open big place for her business and create jobs for other women.
The story of Zainab and her business is just one of the many examples of Izdiharona for economic development clients.
They preferred to blur their face to cultural reason.

loans.use: A portion of Zainab's Group $ 3,000 loan is to buy air-conditioner and over sewing machine

loans.name: Ena

texts.en:
Ena lives in a community in the Department of Atlántida Honduras. She is dedicated to livestock. Age 26 years; she is married and has one child. It is clear that Ena works hard to maintain her family and at night, after a hard day of work, the conditions in the house are not very good due to the lack of electricity. She hopes that with the solar energy system, her child will be able to continue studying and improve the living conditions.
Ena is requesting a loan to purchase a complete solar electric system from SOLUZ Honduras, that will permit to have a better lighting, charge her cell phones, and saving in traditional energy expenditure.

loans.use: to purchase a solar home system that will allow her to reduce spending in kerosene, candles, and improve the home lighting.

loans.name: Regina

texts.es:
Regina es la jefa de su hogar, ella vive con una nieta, se encuentra soltera desde hace ya varios años, su negocio consiste en elaborar comida para vender, lo tiene desde hace 23 años, ella dice que su madre le enseño a desarrollar dicha actividad, en la actualidad trabaja con un horario de seis de la mañana a dos de la tarde, su ventaja es que tiene una cartera estable de clientes frecuentes, por el buen servicio y calidad de productos que ella les ofrece.
Ha buscado ayuda con un financiamiento para poder comprar verduras, carnes, embutidos, condimentos especias, bebidas, etc., para surtir el inventario del comedor y ofrecer un menú más variado, ella espera atender mejor a sus clientes pues de esta manera tendrá mayores ingresos que piensa utilizar para cambiar su estilo de vida familiar.
Sus aspiraciones son lograr tener un negocio más competente, atraer nuevos clientes y tener una vida con menos carencias.

loans.use: comprar verduras, carnes, embutidos, condimentos especias, bebidas, etc., para surtir el inventario del comedor y ofrecer un menú más variado

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Jane would like to buy shares in the stock exchange market.

loans.name: Rebeca

texts.en:
Hardworking and responsible are the two words that describe Rebeca. She is married and has three children. Because of the unemployment rate in Mexico, her husband has never had a steady job. He is a bricklayer and works independently. The need for income to support their family made Rebeca decide to start a business selling ceramic figurines and underwear over a year ago. This work has helped her support her family and provide an education for her kids.

Rebeca needs a loan of $200 which she will use to complete current orders from her customers, and promises to pay back the loan in 3 to 6 months. You can help Rebeca, she will be very thankful.

Translated from Spanish by Ari Vilhjalmsson, Kiva Volunteer.

Trabajadora y responsable es como se puede definir a Rebeca. Ella es casada y tiene tres hijos. La falta de empleo en el país ha contribuido a que su esposo nunca tenga un trabajo formal, él es albañil y trabaja por su cuenta. La necesidad de tener un ingreso para sostener a su familia hizo que Rebeca se decidiera a iniciar su negocio de venta de figuras de cerámica y ropa interior desde hace más de un año. Este trabajo le ha ayudado a sacar adelante a su familia y a ofrecerles educación a sus hijos.

En estos momentos, Rebeca necesita de un crédito por la cantidad de $ 200 dólares con los que espera cumplir con sus clientes que están en espera de sus pedidos, ella se compromete a devolver el préstamo en un plazo de 3 a 6 meses. Tú puedes ayudar a Rebeca, ella te lo agradece sinceramente.

loans.use: Buy merchandise

loans.name: Khalima

texts.en:
N. Khalima worked as a teacher in secondary school before engaging in entrepreneurship activity - however after the civil war, which made life worse for people – she decided to go to bazaar with the aim of providing her grown up children with necessary things. At present, none of them can provide themselves with necessary things, and she has a task to provide them first with education and then with family and separate dwellings.

So, having such plans for nearest future, she tries to develop her business in such a way to answer the market conditions and population demand, and as the only source of income, can meet all requirements of her family.

loans.use: To increase goods assortment

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand his business

loans.name: Elena

texts.es:
Elena V. is 60 years old and lives in her own home. She is a widow and mother of six adult children; three of which are married. Elena tells us that since 1990 she has dedicated herself to the business of renting out chairs and tables that are used for various social events. As we previously mentioned, Elena became a widow at a very young age and had to shoulder the responsibility of supporting her family without the help from her husband. Her husband had started a business as a carpenter along with the help of their eldest son. Today, the business is in the hands of one of her sons. The loan will be used to purchase additional chairs and tables for her business. With the year’s end approaching, the demand to rent tables and chairs increases.

Translated from Spanish by Christian Garcia, Kiva Volunteer.

Elena V. tiene 60 años de edad, vive en casa propia, es viuda con seis hijos, todos mayores de edad; de los cuales tres ya esta casados. La señora Elena nos cuenta que desde el año 1990 se dedica a la actividad de alquiler de sillas y mesas para eventos sociales, particulares y otros. Como ya hemos mencionado anteriormente, Elena enviudó muy joven y tuvo que sobrellevar la responsabilidad de mantener su familia sin el respaldo de su marido, quien en vida tenía una pequeña carpintería, en donde por la necesidad de generar un ingreso para su familia, trabajó por un tiempo con su hijo mayor; hoy en día la carpintería sigue funcionando a cargo de uno de sus hijos. El préstamo lo utilizo para comprar sillas y mesas para alquiler ya que en épocas de fin de año aumenta la cantidad de demanda de alquileres.

loans.use:
Purchase of tables and chairs

Compra de sillas y mesas

loans.name: Pheng

texts.en: Mrs. Pheng S., 40, is a widow and lives with her two kids in Prey Veng province, Cambodia.  She runs a stand in front of a garment factory, selling rice and various kinds of Khmer food to the large number of garment-workers passing by. She can typically earn around $3 per day of profit. One of her children is currently enrolled in school and the other works helping her cook. Mrs. Pheng S. hopes to use this loan to purchase a motor-bike for one of her brothers, who is living with her, to operate a motor-taxi which would enable him to generate more profits for their household.

loans.use: To purchase a motor-bike for one of her brothers to operate a motor-taxi business.

loans.name: Nov

texts.en: Mrs. Nov N., age 40, works with her husband selling sugar cane juice and some grocery products, earning around $3.60 each day. They have two children who are students. She would like to request a loan of $500 in order to purchase an ice cream cart and more grocery products to expand their business and increase their family’s income.

loans.use: To purchase an ice cream cart and more grocery products.

loans.name: Icah

texts.en: Icah, 42, is a mother of 5 children. Her husband, M., is in the waste materials business and earns USD10 a day. So to get some extra income she sells clothes on credit door-to-door, earning USD20 a week. She is asking for a loan of USD75 to expand her business and as a member of MBK is willing to repay this loan within 12 months.

loans.use: For business expansion

loans.name: Muytiatu

texts.en: Mutiatu O. is married with two children. She is 33-years-old and lives in Lagos State, Nigeria. She has been in business since 2001 selling wine,  juice and spirits.. Mrs. O. requests a  loan amount of $450 to purchase additional inventory for resale.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory of wine,  juice and spirits for resale

loans.name: Mwayaya's Mshikamano Group

texts.en:
Mwayaya, 38, a married woman with two children, ages 18 and 13, is a fish seller, a business she started in 2005. She works everyday from 6 a.m. to 7 p.m. and can earn a monthly profit of about $140 from her sales.

Mwayaya previously had a successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan of $1300 to buy more fish, and she will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses in food vending, kiosk operating and shoe selling.

loans.use: To buy more fish for her business.

loans.name: Eric

texts.en:
Eric is a forty-year-old married father of five children. His wife works as a seamstress. He has been selling auto parts of different kinds for over fifteen years. He will use the loan proceeds to purchase more clutch disks and pressure plates from Korea. In Ghana there are no auto parts stores, but there is a high demand for parts as taxis are the main transportation option. His stand operates in an area of Accra called Abossey-Okai that is a conglomeration of hundreds of entrepreneurs who each sell specific auto parts.

In addition to using the loan to support his business, he wants to use the loan to support the operation of his tro-tro. A tro-tro is a van converted into a small bus. Eric is a member of the lending group Respect. The lending group works as a type of social collateral where each member of the group applies pressure on other members to ensure repayment.

loans.use: Eric would like to buy more clutch disks and pressure plates to sell.

loans.name: Mwesigwa Development Group

texts.en: Betty K., the chairperson of Mwesigwa Development Group in Seeta, Uganda, is a married woman with three children attending secondary school.  She also cares for her late sister’s child.  For four years she has managed a business car parts from a garage next to Seeta police post.  She buys the car parts from Kampala City. She works with her husband, who supports her role as a member of the lending group.  In turn, Betty is happy to be part of the lending group because her business is running smoothly thanks to the help of a loan.  To further develop businesses, the Mwesiga Development Group is applying for a loan of $5,000, which will be distributed amongst 24 entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To buy more car parts for the shop.

loans.name: Emelia

texts.en: Emelia E. sells provisions. She is married but her husband's income from his job as a trader is not sufficient for Emelia and her five children. Demand for her goods is high and she is looking to expand her business. She is asking for additional capital to expand her business to increase her profits.

loans.use: To expand her business selling provisions.

loans.name: Charity

texts.en: Charity is 40 years old and a divorced mother with 4 children. She sells cosmetics in her village market to earn a living to take care of her 4 children. All her children are currently in school. Charity says trading in cosmetics is very lucrative and therefore wants to use the loan to buy more boxes of cosmetics to increase her inventory and income. She believes this loan would help her to save for her children’s future. Charity is a member of the group called Anointed Ladies. Members agree to guarantee for each other as a form of social collateral in order to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more boxes of cosmetics

loans.name: Success

texts.en: Success I. is 42 years old, married and has six children. She lives in Benin City, Nigeria, where she makes a living selling food and phone cards. She has been in this business since 2000, and has applied for a loan of $1,200 to buy more food and phone cards to sell to her customers.

loans.use: To buy more food and phone cards to sell.

loans.name: Ibrahima

texts.fr: Ibrahima B. est né le 01 février 1959 à Bambey Serrere dans le département de Bambey. il s'active dans le commerce de poissons depuis cinq ans. il dispose d'une large clientéle constituée des femmes de son quartier.
texts.en:
Ibrahima B. was born on February 1, 1959 in Bambey Serrere in the Bambey region. He has been working in fish trade for the past five years. He has a large customer base made up of women from his district.

Translated from French by Ivana Kostic, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Fish Selling

loans.name: Nasiba

texts.en: R. Nasiba is 35 years old and lives in the Spitamen region. She is married and has 4 children. She trades in the local bazaar and works with wholesale suppliers. She has repeat customers and a good assortment of items. She has worked in this business for 4 years. Mrs. R. Nasiba first applied to MicroInvest in 2008. She is a reliable client who trusts the MicroInvest loan procedure. She applies to KIVA for a business development loan of 2600 STJ (USD $775) for 3 months to import new goods. She thanks KIVA for its support.

loans.use: To import new goods

loans.name: Pauline

texts.en:
Pauline is married with six children and lives in Mbengwi, a rural town about an hour outside of Bamenda, Cameroon.  Pauline runs a small "buy and sell" stand in Mbengwi.  With this loan, she plans to invest in more products to sell at her stand.  Some of these products include rice, onions, groundnut oil, beans, tomatoes, salt, palm oil, and soya beans.  Her business plan shows she will invest 80,000 CFA (approximately $160 USD) of her own savings as well.

This will be Pauline's fourth loan from GHAPE; she has been a member since 2004.  She has been quite successful in the past with her buy-and-sell business due to her location on the main road, the variety of her products, and her reasonable prices.  She goes into Bamenda to purchase most of her products where they are much cheaper and sells them at her stall.  This saves many in her community the transportation costs and the time of going to Bamenda themselves to purchase these items.  She has a strong customer base and is confident that she will be able to increase her sales.  

The profits from this loan will be used for the school fees of Pauline's children.  One of her sons recently failed his exams and is required to redo the year, and she must pay an extra year of schooling for this child.  She also plans to purchase household items such as pots, knives, and dishes for her home.  Pauline does not foresee a problem with her loan repayments as they are quite small repayments every two weeks.  

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount to a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To purchase rice, onions, groundnuts, soya beans, salt, palm oil, garlic, and tomatoes for food stand.

loans.name: Eufemia Nicolasa

texts.es: La Sr. Eufemia tiene 54 años de edad, casada y su esposo es albañil y cultiva frijoles y plátanos a 50 Km. al sur de la capital. La clienta habita en Healeah,  ella es ama de casa y recibe una pensión del seguro social por haber laborado como conserje en un colegio por más de 15 años. Todos sus hijos ya son mayores de edad y sus planes es la construcción de su casa y aumentar la cantidad de cultivo de frijoles. Agracias a los prestamos de Afodenic lograr sus planes podrán realizarlos, sus metas de salir adelante con sus cultivos y la construcción de su casa, de su baño y servicio higiénico para obtener mayor comodidad en su casa.
texts.en:
Eufemia is 54 years old, married, and her husband is a bricklayer and cultivates beans and bananas 50 Km south of the capitol. Eufemia lives in Healeah, she is the woman of the house and receives a pension from social security for having worked as an adviser at a college for more than 15 years. All of her children are grown and her plans are to to build onto her home and improve the quantity of beans they cultivate. Thanks to the loans of Afodenic, she can accomplish her goals of advancing cultivation and building a hygienic bathroom to be more comfortable in her home.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Jung, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase construction materials to improve her home.

loans.name: Jorge

texts.es:
El Sr. Jorge F. tiene 37 años de edad, esta casado y vive armoniosamente con su esposa, Laura Blanco de 27 años de edad, tienen dos hijos menores en edad escolar, que participan de los quehaceres de la casa. 
Esta pareja se dedica a la venta de calzados y celulares a 50 metros del centro comercial nº 1 de la Ciudad de Cnel. Oviedo, conocieron el negocio a través del padre de Laura, quien es un gran emprendedor, luego de contraer nupcias ellos decidieron aceptar el desafío de iniciar el micro emprendimiento por sí solos, la experiencia de la señora, que proviene de una familia de comerciantes fijo el rumbo y sus conocimientos de ventas aseguran el éxito del negocio.
El préstamo solicita para la compra de calzados deportivos, y para iniciar un negocio de venta de celulares, venta de accesorios, etc.
texts.en:
Mr. Jorge F. is 37-years old and lives happily married with his wife Laura Blanco, 27. They have 2 children, still too young for school, who help with household chores. The couple sells footwear and cellular phones in a shop 50 meters from Centro Comercial nº 1 (a shopping center) in the city of Coronel Oviedo. They started in the business through Laura’s father, an experienced entrepreneur. After marrying they decided to take on the challenge of starting a small business for themselves; Laura’s experience, coming from a family of small business owners, and her sales expertise will ensure the success of the business. The requested loan is for the purchase of athletic shoes and to start a store selling cellular phones and accessories.

Translated from Spanish by Vivian Lu, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of footwear, cellular phones and accessories

loans.name: Cresencia

texts.en:
Cresencia R. is 30 years old with one child.  Married at a young age, the couple settled in Gango, Ozamiz City. Her husband drives "tri-sikad" (3-wheeled motor transportation) from Mondays to Fridays.  For additional income he drives a multi-cab for hire on weekends.  Cresencia helps her husband by fish vending in the little barangay of Gango.  A small table is all they have to start up their business.  Neighbors, and people in the nearby barangays are her customers.  She never gets tired of making her display in a barangay market. She purchase fish from Bagsakan in the city market, or somewhere in Oroquieta City or Pagadian City.
She made arrangements for wholesale purchase of fish on a cash basis.  Cresencia's business has no trade or business name but she promptly pay taxes in the barangay.  They ask helped from Paglaum for additional capital for her fish selling.  The loan will also help her husband to generate income for their household. The couple aspires to increase more profit in order to have their own motorcycle for easy transportation. They also hope to have more income so that they can build their own house and be able to send her child to college.

loans.use: addtional working capital for fish selling

loans.name: Rosa Violeta

texts.es:
Rosa es socia del Bancomunal San Judas Tadeo.
Rosa es madre soltera, tiene 38 años, tiene una hija de 5 años que esta en la escuela.
El negocio que tiene es venta de golosinas en la casa de su tía. 
Estudio enfermería técnica, ejerció por un tiempo y cuando la solicitan va a trabaja, pero  es un trabajo muy pesado, por eso  empezó a trabajaba en un cafetería por tres años, le gusto el negocio y quiere poner en su casa una tienda, ella esta arreglando su casa.  También trabaja limpiando casas. 
Necesita un préstamo de 2400 soles, para el arreglo de su casa, poner piso y compra de golosinas. 
Con los ahorros y préstamos  en Finca a comprado estante, se siente mas realizada por que cuenta con un capital para invertir ve como las socias tiene iniciativa para surgir en sus negocios,  eso le contagia a ella. Siente que  tiene opción para salir adelante.
El sueño de Rosa es tener un depósito de venta de gas en su casa.
texts.en:
Rosa is a member of the San Judas Tadeo Community Bank. She is a 38-year-old single mother of a 5-year-old girl who attends school. Rosa's business is selling sweets from her aunt's home. She studied to be a nursing technician, and practiced for a while, but it is a very difficult job. So, she began working in a cafeteria and enjoyed working there for three years. Currently, Rosa cleans houses and is building a shop in her home. Rosa would like a loan for 2,400 Peruvian nuevos soles (US $750). She will use the money to build a shop, install flooring, and purchase sweets. With her savings and previous loans from Kiva's partner FINCA Peru, she has purchased shelving. Rosa is grateful for her association with the community bank. She feels more secure because she has working capital, and watching other women take initiative in their businesses has increased her own enthusiasm. She knows that she has the opportunity to get ahead. Rosa's dream is to one day sell gas canisters from her home.

Translated from Spanish by Kris Vickery, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To build a shop, install flooring, and purchase sweets

loans.name: Maria Esperanza

texts.es: La Señora María Esperanza R. tiene 35 años, y su estado civil es casada. La actividad económica a la que Doña María se dedica es pulpería. Hace más de cinco años que se dedica a este negocio ya que surge por la necesidad de una fuente de ingresos. Doña María tiene los propósitos de aumentar su negocio por que sus clientes buscarían los productos que ofrece. El financiamiento es para capital de trabajo como granos básicos, gaseosas, golosinas y cosméticos. En sus deseos esta el obtener la reputación necesaria en su comarca y así vender lo que el cliente necesita. La cantidad solicitada es de C$ 15.000 córdobas a un plazo de 12 meses.
texts.en:
Mrs. Maria Esperanza R. is 35 years old and married. Maria works in her grocery store that she has owned for the past 5 years. She started it due to the need for a source of income. Maria plans on expanding her business because her customers will seek out the products she offers. The loan is for the purchase of basic grains, soft drinks, candies and cosmetics. She hopes to gain a good reputation in her area by selling what her customers need. The amount needed is C$ 15.000 córdobas to be repaid in 12 months.

Translated from Spanish by Rachel Crouch, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Jessica

texts.es: Jessica tiene 29 años, vive con su pareja Andrés y su único hijo Jeremy, de 4 años de edad, en su casa propia. Se dedica a la venta de productos de belleza por pedido, al saber que podía trabajar desde casa decidió dedicarse a ello, ya que requería de una actividad que no le quite mucho tiempo y le permita pasar más tiempo con su hijo, el cual es su adoración. Le gusta mucho su trabajo, ya que puede ir de casa en casa visitando a sus amigas y ofreciendo sus productos; además ha puesto una vitrina en la bodega de su madre donde se exhiben mejor, y recibe más pedidos. Jessica está muy contenta con su trabajo ya que le permite generar un ingreso extra al sueldo de su esposo, pudiendo darse sus gustitos personales, como ella dice, y mejorar la economía de su hogar. En el futuro quisiera tener una boutique en su domicilio y obtener mayores ganancias. Este es segundo préstamo con Microfinanzas Prisma, siendo muy puntual en sus pagos, además que el banco comunal en el que trabaja, llamado “Cristo Morado”es muy unido haciendo más fácil y bonito su trabajo. Con el dinero que solicita adquirirá mayor cantidad de productos de belleza para aumentar sus ventas.
texts.en:
Jessica is 29 years old and lives with her husband, Andrés, and her only son, Jeremy, who is 4 years old, in her own home. She makes a living selling beauty products by order. Knowing that she could work from home she decided to do it, since she required an activity that wouldn't take up too much time and allow her to spend more time with her son, whom she adores. She really enjoys her work since she can go from house to house visiting her friend and offering her products. Furthermore, she has set up a display case in her mother's general store, to better exhibit her products, and she has received more orders. Jessica is very pleased with her job because it allows her to generate extra income on top of what her husband earns, so she can treat herself to personal pleasures, as she says, and improve the economic situation of her household. In the future she would like to have a boutique in her home and increase her earnings. This is her second loan through Kiva partner Microfinanzas Prisma, and she has been very punctual with her payments. Furthermore, the community bank she works with, called "Cristo Morado", is very helpful to her business. With the money she is requesting she plans to purchase a larger quantity of beauty products to increase her sales.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a larger quantity of beauty products

loans.name: Faaiuga

texts.en: Faaiuga P., 31, is married with 1 child.  She has 3 years of experience in the pig farming business. She sells to the general public 4 days a week. She has no previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 166 Tala.  SPBD loans are Faaiuga’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase wire for fencing, cement, wheelbarrow, and coconuts for pig food.

loans.name: Men

texts.en:
Mrs. Men M., 53, and her husband, Mr. Touk Ros, 48, were married in 1984 and have five children: three sons and two daughters. Two of their children are married and live outside the family home. The family lives in the suburb of Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Men has been selling fish and eggs for twenty years. Her husband has been raising ducks for four years. She is asking for her first loan of $1,000 for her husband to raise ducks.

loans.use: To use for raising ducks.

loans.name: Elsie

texts.en:
Elsie P. is from the town of Lallo, Cagayan. She is 38 years old. Elsie is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Elsie owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling food products in the local community.

Elsie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elsie is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to expand her business. This loan will be taken by Elsie from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of pioneer microfinance institutions in the Philippines committed to serve the needy in Central and Northern Luzon through socio-economic development and holistic transformation.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Zikrillo

texts.en:
Zikrillo, 37, has been married since the age of 24 to the mother of his four children. Zikrillo has worked in agriculture since he was a young, his father having taught him how to responsibly work with each crop, and now, with the help of his wife and adult children, he derives a sense of dignity from his work. As a consequence, he treats each plant with affection and care until they are ready for harvest, at which point he takes them to sell in the market.

Zikrillo would very much like to buy a house in the city to ensure the well-being and tranquility of his children, and in this way improve their quality of life. The money that he is soliciting is for the purchase of seeds, chemical fertilizers, fuels and lubricants. Let’s support this hard-working and talented man so that he can obtain his goals!

More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes: its role as a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets including Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

However, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous, and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment, forcing hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing of seeds, mineral fertilizer, fuels and lubricants.

loans.name: Henry Daniel

texts.es:
el sr. Henry G. se dedica al comercio desde hace 2 años, el cual ha sabido administrar muy bien, ya que el nos comento que vendia su producto en carro, ahora tiene una tienda.
esta tienda esta ubicada en la calle del comercio del municipio de trojes, Henry se caracteriza porque da muy buenos precios y por la amabilidad con que trata a sus clientes, su afan es querer ser un empresario de exito, el a cuidado muy bien su negocio.
texts.en:
For the past 2 years Mr. Henry G. has worked in sales, which he has known how to administer very well. He told us that he used to sell his product in a cart, but now has a store. This store is located on the commercial street of the municipality of Trojes. Henry is characterized by the good prices he gives and by the kindness with which he treats his clients. His desire is to be a successful businessman. He has cared for his business very well.

Translated from Spanish by Aimee Sostowski, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of clothing for ladies, gentlemen and children

loans.name: Julia Teresa

texts.en:
Julia is a member of the communal bank “Mujeres Perseverantes” (Persevering Women) and lives in the city of Pucallpa. Julia has a stall at Pucallpa’s massive Bellavista market where she sells chicken and different fruits, depending on the season. When I visited her recently in the late morning, she had already sold most of her chickens and had some peppers, plantains and oranges for sale.

Julia has been working with Manuela Ramos for two years and used her very first loan to fix up a house on her property so she could rent it out to tenants. At that time she had a business selling fruit juices but left that for her current enterprise at the Bellavista market, which she finds less strenuous. According to Julia, her loans from Manuela Ramos have helped her to maintain enough capital to keep her business going.

Julia plans to use this loan of 1500 soles to purchase 30 hens and to fix up her stand so that she can keep them there. These hens are of a higher quality than the chickens she sells currently, so she hopes to be able to make a better profit with them.

Julia is a single mother of a five-year-old daughter. Her goal is to eventually have a business out of her home which would be easier for her daughter, who currently must rise every day before dawn to accompany her mother to the market. In this short video clip, Julia talks about the home-based business she would like to have eventually: a stationary and copy shop, which she thinks would do well due to the fact that there are many schools in her area.

video.title: Kiva Entrepreneur Julia Teresa from  Peru

loans.use: To buy 30 hens and fix up a market stall.

loans.name: Alec

texts.en: Alec is a 34-year-old single man. He has owned a car repair shop since 2000.  Alec is requesting to borrow $1,000 to purchase new tools for his shop so he can satisfy the heavy demands of the market and help increase his income.

loans.use: purchase new tools

loans.name: Folashade

texts.en: Folashade sells frozen food and foodstuff and has been in business for five years. She joined LAPO a year after starting her business. She is requesting for the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase frozen food and foodstuff in large quantity this she said will enable her meet the demand of customers.Folashade is 45 years old and married with two children. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase foodstuff and frozen food to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy farming products and merchadise for his store.

loans.name: Victoria

texts.es:
Victoria es una mujer de 45 años de edad, vive es su casa propia, tenía 8 hijos, pero uno de ellos murió hace poco tiempo. Debido a esto y por la pena que la aquejaba, Victoria descuidó la alimentación de sus animales, pues su actividad cotidiana es la crianza de cerdos y vacas. Con el paso del tiempo ha ido recuperando su ánimo y ha volcado nuevamente sus fuerzas hacia sus animales. En el caso de los cerdos, los engordar durante 6 meses, y luego los comercializa en una carnicería de la ciudad. Por otro lado, durante la crianza de las vacas, aprovecha al máximo la leche, la cual recolecta y elabora deliciosos quesos que vende al por mayor a los comerciantes del mercado. Victoria ama sus actividades, ya que mediante ellas educó a todos sus hijos, mientras que su esposo se dedica a la agricultura, de ese modo, juntos cubren las necesidades de su hogar.
Este es su cuarto préstamo con MFP, ella se siente muy cómoda en su banco comunal y durante todo este tiempo no ha descuidado el pago de sus cuotas. El dinero que ahora solicita lo invertirá en la compra de alimentos balanceados para la alimentación de sus cerdos.
texts.en:
Victoria is 45 years old and lives in her own home. She has eight children, but one passed away recently. Victoria raises pigs and cattle, but while in mourning, she wasn't always able to feed and care for her animals. Fortunately, time has helped to lessen her grief and she has returned to her work. She fattens pigs for six months, then takes them to be sold at a butcher shop in the city. When one of her cows has been bred, Victoria gets as much from the milk as she can. She makes delicious cheeses and sells them wholesale to merchants. Victoria loves her work; it has allowed her to provide all her children with an education. Her husband is a farmer, and together they're able to provide their household with all the necessities. This is Victoria's fourth loan with MFP; she's very content with her community bank and has never neglected her payments. Your contribution will help Victoria to purchase feed for her pigs.

Translated from Spanish by Corinne Gilroy, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying pig feed

loans.name: Cristina

texts.en:
Cristine is managing a general store for ten years.  She is 61 years old and still very diligent in doing her business.  She is married and blessed with 12 children and they all have their own families. Her business is of big help in providing the needs of their family. 

Cristina is praying for good health condition.  Her income is not enough to support the medicine of his husband who is ill. Through her business income, she can provide the medicines of his husband.  She is hoping that the KIVA lenders will grant her loan request of PHP13,000.  She will use the loan to buy more stocks for her store.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her business

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty owns a retail shop selling day-to-day essentials. She wants to use this loan to buy more merchandise like boxes of soap, cartons of salt, sacks of sugar, and jerry cans of cooking oil. On average, she serves 20 customers a day. Her challenges include defaulters and the rainy season, because, when it rains, very few customers come to her retail shop which is in a muddy place on the outskirts of Kampala. She pays for transport costs to and from her suppliers in Kikuubo, one of the busiest places in Kampala.

Betty is a 46-year-old married woman with four children between the ages of 13 and 22 years. All her children go to school. She owns a five-room house where she lives with seven people. The family has access to electricity but no piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees and medication.

Betty has been in her business for six years and with MCDT for ten years, now on her 17th loan working with the same group mates. Betty hopes to see her business grow stronger and wants to start selling only wholesale.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise like sacks of sugar, soap and boxes of salt

loans.name: Baast

texts.en:
Baast T. is a 50-year-old widow who lives with her three children and one grandchild in the Khovd Province of Western Mongolia. The family lives together in a "ger," a yurt or traditional nomadic Mongolian tent. Her oldest daughter, 26, works as a bank teller. Her younger children, ages 17 and 14, attend a local secondary school, and her grandson, age 3, attends a local kindergarten. 

T. operates a clothing business in a shipping container in the local market. She started her business in 1999 in a stand inside the market, but she was able to buy her own container and now has more space for her products. Eventually, she plans to purchase another container so that she can have two locations from which to sell her clothing and hopefully improve her profits. Because of her hard work and good business sense, T. has been able to improve her family’s quality of life and buy a car. She hopes that she can help her oldest daughter and grandson move into a home of their own. She is requesting a 2,300,000 tugrug (approx. $1620 USD) loan to purchase a large amount of winter clothes for her retail business.		

XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of winter clothes for her retail business

loans.name: Zanabayar

texts.en:
Zanabazar N. is 34 years old and lives with her husband and six-year-old son in Bayan-Ulgii province, one of Mongolia's western provinces. She runs a small carpentry shop with her husband.

Her husband is a talented carpenter who is good at making wooden furniture and other wooden objects. He is now making traditional wooden furniture to order but is currently lacking in working capital for making large furniture.

He mostly spends his business profits, after family basic expenses, for buying wood and other necessary materials for his business. Zanabazar says that she would like to expand her family carpentry business and be able to make large furniture for locals. She further adds that her family is working hard to expand the business and be more successful.

She requests a loan for working capital to purchase necessary materials for the business. About XacBank: XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest micro-finance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save. To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.

loans.use: To purchase raw material for the business

loans.name: Lenie

texts.en:
Lenie M. is from the village of Estrella, San Guillermo, Isabela. She is 32 years old. Lenie is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Lenie owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Lenie earns approximately PHP 8,000 every crop season for these activities.

In 2009, Lenie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lenie is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to re-open her retail store. This will be the first loan taken out by Lenie from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to re-open her retail store

loans.name: Unurjargal

texts.en:
Unurjargal C. is 39 years old and lives with her husband and daughter in Arkhangai province, Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Her 17 year old daughter attends a local secondary school and her husband helps with the family business. Unurjargal manages a consumer goods trading business and food cafe in her town. She started selling consumer goods in 2002 and quickly built a consistent operation. She used her savings to recently open her cafe. Unurjargal has worked hard to manage both of her businesses and has gained much experience as a businesswoman.

Today, both operations have reached a stable level and she has grown her capital to a level exceeding 4,000,000 tugrugs. She attributes her success to her good customer service skills. Unurjargal is requesting a 3,000,000 tugrug loan to purchase groceries for her food cafe.

loans.use: To purchase groceries for her food cafe.

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith B. is from the village of Caputol in Aloran, Misamis Occidental. She is 53 years old. Judith is married and has four adult children. To make a living, Judith owns & operates a motorcycle transport business. Judith has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2000, Judith joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Judith has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Judith is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory & as working capital. This loan will be the 16th loan taken out by Judith from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: As working capital

loans.name: Beatriz

texts.en:
Beatriz L. is from the village of Batangan, Valencia City. She is 49 years old and married with four school-aged children. To make a living, Beatriz owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. She's been in this business for over two years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Beatriz joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Beatriz is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP to invest in expanding the business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand the borrower's business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business.

loans.name: Eva

texts.en:
Eva A. is a married woman who supports her family by selling Ready to Wear clothes and running a general store. She lives in Brgy Basak, Cuayan, Negros Occidental with her husband and their three children who are between 20 and 27 years old. One of their children already has a family and the other two children work and help the family.

Eva has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2002 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her ready to wear and general store business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 8,000.

Eva is now borrowing PHP 19,500 so that she can sustain her ready to wear business and her general store. This will be her 12th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 21,500, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Eva aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Omukyepatiko Junction Group B, Kihihi

texts.en:
At the top left is T. Night who also happens to be at the far right in the photo of her lending group in Kihihi. She is 34 years old and married with four children aged 15, 12, 10 and 6 years and she has operated a hotel (restaurant) business in Nyalumoni trading centre for ten years.

Night is grateful that she is able to make 50,000/= as profits amidst the heavy competition in her business and, since she has a dream of expanding the hotel further, she hopes her profits will increase.

Night says that she started her business with a loan from Feed the Children Uganda, now Pearl Microfinance, and she does not regret the trend that her business has taken since she is able to pay fees for her children’s education with much ease.

Night needs a loan to be able to increase her working capital by stocking more foodstuffs for her hotel and buying new utensils for improved service.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs and more utensils for her restaurant

loans.name: José Luís

texts.es:
El señor José Luís C. A. tiene ya más de nueve años dedicándose a la elaboración y venta de piñatas, también vende cascaron de huevo para la temporada de pascua.
Don José Luís tiene un problema que se le descompuso el vehiculo que utiliza para trasportar la mercancía, y por el momento no cuenta con el dinero necesario para poder repararla. Es por eso que está solicitando el préstamo, y así poder entregar los pedidos a tiempo. 
Planea pagar el crédito con las ganancias del negocio, ya que también es la fuente de ingreso de su familia.
texts.en:
José Luís C. A. has been working for more than nine years making and selling piñatas. He also sells eggshells for the Easter season. José Luís has a problem: the vehicle he uses for transporting his merchandise broke down, and for the moment he doesn't have the money to repair it. This is why he is asking for this loan, so he can fill his orders on time. He plans to pay off the loan with the earnings from his business, which is also his family's source of income.

Translated from Spanish by Danielle Maxson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Repair car for distribution of piñatas and eggshells

loans.name: Grupo De Mujeres "las Divinas" Group

texts.es:
Este grupo de personas residen en Cantón Las Flores, San Bernardino, Suchitepéquez, y solicitaron un  
crédito en la Asociación ASDIR, ya que contaban con una venta pero por la falta de capital de trabajo no 
podían darle continuidad a dichas ventas, por lo que presentando su solicitud de crédito se les autorizó un 
capital de trabajo el cual lo invirtieron sus ventas de repostería, medicina, ropa, panes y servicios de costu-
rería, los cuales comercializan en el municipio de San Bernardino Such. Y que a través de estas ventas 
mejoraran sus condiciones de vida ya que no solamente contaran con el poyo económico de sus esposos
sino que ahora también ellas contribuirán  con los gastos del hogar y esto se debe al apoyo crediticio
que la Asociación brinda a estas familias.
texts.en:
This group of people lives in Cantón Las Flores, San Bernardino, Suchitepéquez. They asked for a loan in the Asociación ASDIR, since they had a sale but due to a lack of capital, couldn't continue with said sale. They presented their loan application and their working capital was authorized. They invested their earnings in pastry making, medicine, clothes, bread and tailoring, which they offer in the town of San Bernardino Such. Through these sales, they improved their living conditions since then they not only have the economic support of their husbands, they contribute to the household expenses as well. This is due to the loan support the Asociación offers these families.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Re-structuring merchandise these people have with their businesses, but due to lack of capital they didn't continue their activities and with this loan they will outfit their small businesses again.

loans.name: Igorora Tukore Association, Ibanda Group

texts.en:
This 48-year-old female, K. Agnes, is hardworking and dedicated to her banana plantation enterprise that she has run for over ten years. This has earned her a profit of 200,000 Ugandan shillings monthly which has helped in providing basic needs for her six children.

This loan will be an incentive for Agnes to purchase farm tools like hoes and fertilizer and to modernize her plantation to improve on the banana crop which is commonly used by customers for making local dishes. This will increase Agnes’s sales revenue and enable her to pay her daily bills including her children’s school fees.

Agnes belongs to a group that hold each other accountable and insure one another in paying back the loan.

loans.use: To purchase hoes, mulches  and fertilizer for her banana plantation

loans.name: Anne B.

texts.fr: G. Anne B. vit depuis une dizaine d'année au quartier Irédé à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à RAMAN Tidjani, Anne est mère de deux enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Anne vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple assure ensemble les différentes charges familiales. N'ayant jamais été à l'école, Anne mène comme activité, la vente de maïs et d'akassa (aliment local fait à base d'amidon de maïs) à son domicile.
