Eleaich has owned a small shop and  has been a tailor in the  Sakina neighborhood of Arusha for 19 years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $225. Every day she works at her business from 8am to 12.30pm. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy another sewing machine for her business. She is hopping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and save money for future use.  

Eliaich is 38 years old, married, and has one child: ages 12. She also cares for two additional dependants.

loans.use: To buy another sewing machine in order to expand her business.

loans.name: Alaimalo

texts.en:
Alaimalo S., 37, is married with four children. She has one year of experience in the cattle-farming business. She sells to the public one day per week. She has no previous loans with SPBD, Kiva's partner. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (about $208).

SPBD loans are Alaimalo’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. All of her loan will be used to purchase fence to secure the cows from escaping. Her husband helps her with the business.

loans.use: Purchase a fence to secure the cows

loans.name: Merlita

texts.en:
Merlita B. is 37 years old, married, and blessed with four children. She lives in Palacapao, Quezon, Bukidnon in the southern Philippines. Her husband works as a security guard in a company.

Merlita has a variety (sari-sari) store and also sells ready-to-wear (RTW) clothes. She started the business with a small amount of capital that came from their savings. Currently, Merlita's store and RTW business are good, but she wants to increase the stock in her store to meet the demands of her customers and generate more income. She is applying for a loan of PHP 25,000 from HSPFI (a Kiva partner). If her loan is granted, this will be her 13th loan cycle. She dreams of seeing her children finish school and earn degrees in the future.

loans.use: To purchase additional grocery items for sale

loans.name: Luisa

texts.en: Luisa K., 26, is married with one child.  She has two years of experience in the popcorn business. She sells to her villagers five days per week. She has no previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 125 Tala. SPBD loans are Luisa’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase popcorn, butter, plastic containers, salt and plastic bags.

loans.name: Luzviminda

texts.en:
Luzviminda C. is a rice farmer. She is 60 years old and has 7 children. She is already a widow as her husband died from an illness. Though she is old, she is still strong and able to do business. Presently, her children are helping her on their farm. She hires laborers to work in her rice field.

She is asking a loan of PHP 6,000 (USD 125) from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy fertilizers, seeds, herbicides and fungicides. The loan will help improve the soil condition of the farm. Moreover, it will help to protect her rice from insects. 

CEVI aims to help small business like hers to grow. CEVI gives not just loans but also provides training and insurance coverage.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, seeds, herbicides and fungicides for rice farming.

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en:
Rosalina is married to Domingo C., a seller of agricultural fertilizer in their village. They are blessed with 3 children; Lorelie is 29 years old and an Overseas Filipino Worker (OFW), Randy is 27 years old & a farmer, and finally Rogie is 23 years old and a Nursing graduate. Rosalina and Comingo both still live in their family home in Barangay La Paz, Cabatuan, Isabela. 

Rosalina owns and operates her own tailoring business and she specializes in curtains. For as long as she has been in business she has not had the success she would have hoped. Rosalina wants to change this and is asking for a loan of PHP 8,000 to help expand her business. She believes that patience should always be accompanied by hard work in order to become successful in every business endeavor.

loans.use: Business Expansion

loans.name: Đặng Thị

texts.en:
Nhị Đặng THị (804990146) is a 47-year-old female living in the town of Ý Yên. She is married and has four school-aged children.

Nhị owns and operates a business raising pigs for sale. She has been engaged in this business for over ten years and earns approximately 4,600,000 VND a month.

In 1999, Nhị joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000,000 VND from TYM Fund. This previous loan was used to build a shelter for her pigs.

Nhị is now requesting a new loan of 20,000,000 VND which will be used to invest in expanding her business. The loan will be her 9th loan from TYM Fund. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Hermelinda

texts.es: Hermelinda tiene 45 años, vive junto al padre de sus 6 hijos, de los cuales, sólo 3 de ellos viven con ellos. La gran parte de su casa es de madera, pero pronto planea construir otra parte con material noble (cemento. Cuando era pequeña realizaba los trabajos agrícolas junto a sus padres, pero no le gustaba ser agricultora, proponiéndose para el futuro dedicarse al comercio de frutas y verduras. Una vez que formó su propia familia, le propuso la idea a su pareja, quien no estuvo de acuerdo en un primer momento, pero Hermelinda perseveró y finalmente terminó convertida en una próspera comerciante de frutas de su pueblo. Ahora su esposo la ayuda las veces que tiene que ir de compras a las chacras más lejanas en busca de precios muy bajos para pesar y cargar las arrobas o racimos de plátanos (12 kilos) y en el caso de naranjas compran por cientos. Ella es una vendedora muy dinámica, le gusta progresar a base de su trabajo, por ello que todas sus ganancias las va invirtiendo en la mejora de su casa y la educación de sus hijos. Hermelinda incentiva a todos sus compañeros del banco comunal para que cumplan con sus pagos, dando el ejemplo ella misma, trabajando con mucha responsabilidad. El dinero que solicita lo invertirá en la compra de plátanos y naranjas para incrementar su capital de trabajo.
texts.en:
Hermelinda is a 45-year-old woman who lives with the father of her 6 children, 3 of whom live with them. Her house is mostly made of wood, but she is planning on soon building the other part with sturdier material—cement. When she was young, she used to work in agriculture alongside her parents, but she did not like that. Instead, she aimed to work as a fruit and vegetable vendor. As soon as she started her own family, she proposed the idea to her partner, who did not go along with it at first. However, Hermelinda persevered until she finally became a prosperous green grocer in her city. Her husband now helps her anytime time she has to visit the most distant farms in search of low prices to weigh and carry the banana bunches and oranges by the hundreds. She is a dynamic merchant who likes to get ahead by means of her labor. For this reason, she has invested her profits in home improvement and in providing an education for her children. Hermelinda motivates the other group members of the microfinance institute so that they can make their payments on time, setting the example herself and working responsibly. She will invest the money that she is requesting in purchasing bananas and oranges so that she can increase her working capital.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase merchandise

loans.name: God's Way Group

texts.en:
Elizabeth is fifty-six years old. She is married and has given birth to a son. She is a trader and sells provisions on a table in her house.

Elizabeth is the leader of a trust bank group called “God’s Way”. She is seated first on the right. The members of this group are mostly traders, food vendors and or farmers and they work to support their spouses to provide for their families. They buy their raw materials, wares or goods from other towns and sometimes from nearby communities and sell at the local market square. Some of them trek to other towns to sell on their market days as well. The members have been in business for sometime and have amassed a great deal of experience in their businesses. It is in light of this that they are requesting a loan to procure more goods to expand their businesses.

The members of the group guarantee for one another as social collateral to access the loan. It is their desire to give their children a good education.

loans.use: To buy more provisions to sell

loans.name: Women Of Progress Group

texts.es:
El Grupo de Mujeres de Progreso está conformado por mujeres luchadoras, trabajadoras y aplicadas entre estas se encuentra Cruz Mayra P. C., Karla Vanessa T., Xiomara Vilche Gaitán y Martina Concepción V. L.. Este grupo son provenientes de Piedra Menuda una comarca de Nindirí de difícil acceso ya que  el transporte tan solo pasa dos veces al día.

La coordinadora del grupo es Cruz Mayra P. C. de 38 años de edad quien está casada y tiene dos hijos menores de edad uno de ellos tiene 10 años y un bebe de 10 meses. Esta señora hace dos años que comenzó vendiendo maní crudo pero por idea de su esposo e iniciativa propia decidió ornear el maní y ganar más. Actualmente vende maní horneado y huso de res. 

La meta inmediata de  P. es seguir adelante con su negocio y poder aumentar sus ventas sin embargo para ello necesita invertir en la compra de su materia prima que es el maní.

Las otras integrantes del grupo son la señora Xiomara Viche Gaitán de 25 años de edad quien tiene una pequeña pulpería, Karla Vanessa T. de 27 años de edad quien vende ropa, cosméticos y realiza rifas y la señora Martina Concepción Viches de 34 años de edad que también comercializa con ropa. 
 
Este grupo ya tuvo su primer préstamo en Adim lo que les ayudo a incrementar su inventario en productos y obtener mayores ganancias. En la actualidad ellas necesitan de ingresos para adquirir nuevas mercaderías y así  ir creciendo poco a poco sus negocios.
texts.en:
The Women of Progress Group is made up of fighting, hard-working, and industrious women, including Cruz Mayra P. C., Karla Vanessa T., Xiomara Vilche Gaitán and Martina Concepción V. L.. This group comes from Piedra Menuda, an area of Nindirí that is difficult to access because there is only transportation there twice a day. The group leader is Cruz Mayra P. C., who is 38 years old, is married, and has two young children, who are 10 years old and 10 months old. Two years ago, this woman started selling raw peanuts, but based on her husband’s idea and her own initiative, she decided to season the peanuts, and she earned more. At present, she sells baked peanuts and animal bones. P.’s immediate goal is to go forward with her business and be able to increase her sales, but for this, she needs to invest in the purchase of raw materials, such as peanuts. The other members of the group are Mrs. Xiomara Viche Gaitán, who is 25 years old and has a small grocery store; Karla Vanessa T., who is 27 years old and sells clothing, cosmetics, and holds raffles; and Mrs. Martina Concepción Viches, who is 34 years old and sells clothing. This group has already had its first loan with Adim, which helped them increase their inventory of products and have more earnings. At present, they need income to buy more merchandise and, in this way, grow their business little by little.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy peanuts and animal bones

loans.name: Sabohat

texts.en:
J. Sabohat is a brave married woman who works hard for the good of her two children. The strict discipline she uses with her children allows her to count on her household’s advice and support in working the fields. Sabohat’s children’s grateful attitude continues to encourage her, and they have learned many lessons during this time that they can use when they form their own households. What Sabohat urgently needs right now are fertilizers and other chemicals for cultivating her land and to be prepared for upcoming growing season. Sabohat doesn’t just need good land; she also needs a friendly hand to help her out.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and with it’s famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.  And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. 
But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics.  The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy.  In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable.  These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.  While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. 

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasw of seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Jamal

texts.en:
Jamal is 34, married, and the father of three children. He owns a shop where he sells computer-related items and accessories, and provides maintenance services.

In order to boost his sales and to provide better customer service, Jamal is requesting a loan in the amount of U.S. $2,000. He will use this loan to purchase computer accessories. Become a part of the success of this business by helping Jamal improve it. He greatly appreciates your support!

loans.use: Purchase computer accessories.

loans.name: Heng

texts.en: Heng S., age 35, is married with two children. He lives with his wife (pictured) in Battambong Province. To make a living, he and his wife sell groceries, typically earning $9 per day. Both of them have to work hard everyday to ensure a good living for their family. Therefore, S. is seeking to increase his income and improve his business. He is asking for a loan of $1000 to purchase more groceries to expand his business. By doing so, he believes that he will be able to achieve a good standard of living for his family.

loans.use: To buy groceries for her store.

loans.name: Chidima

texts.en: Chidima is 38 years old and married with 3 children. She sells text books. Chidima hopes to receive a loan amount of N140, 000 to purchase more supplies of text books to sell. Chidima says thanks to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more supplies of text books to sell

loans.name: Rosario

texts.en:
Rosario 48 years old and a resident of Jurisdiction Amulung Cagayan.  She is married to Celestino a local farmer in their village. They are blessed with four children: Rowena, who is 30 years old, a college graduate and is now working as an elementary public teacher in their village; Gilbert who is 28 years old, also a college graduate, and also a public high school teacher; Rolando who is 26 years old, also a college graduate and now is working as an Overseas Filipino worker in a factory in Qatar; and finally, Mary-Ann who is 19 years old, and is now  college student learning Information Technology.  Two of Rosario's children are already married.  

 
Rosario’s husband manages their farming business while Rosaerio is works in a general store business in their village.  At the general store, she earns a weekly income of PHP1,500. Recently, she has wanted her business to grow so that she can have an increase in her income. So, she is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders amounting to PHP15,000 to purchase additional items such as sugar, canned goods, coffee, ten cases of bottled soft drinks, etc. She believes that this will really help her business and her family to have a progressing standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase additional grocery items for her store

loans.name: Sharavdorj

texts.en:
Sharavdorj D. is 29 years old and lives with his wife and three-year-old son in a house in the Govi-Altai province of southwest Mongolia. His wife is an accountant for a business center, his son attends a local kindergarten and D. operates his own raw material transportation service. He has had his business since 2007 and transports raw materials from Govi-Altai to Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. On his return trips to Govi-Altai from Ulaanbaatar, he transports oil from the petrol company Magnai Trade or cargo from Narantuul, a large central market in the city. One day, D. would like to be able to purchase a larger truck in order to haul more materials to and from Ulaanbaatar. Now, however, he is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug loan so that he can purchase four new wheels for his trailer which he uses to haul materials.

XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.

loans.use: To purchase four new wheels for his trailer which he uses to haul materials

loans.name: Alverlyn

texts.en:
Alverlyn V. is 32 years old and resides in the village of Barangay Paniki, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. After high school, she married Mr. Marcelo V., Jr. and they are blessed with two children. They aim to uplift their standard of living to give their children a better future. They endure hardships and difficulties in earning a living for their survival and for the schooling of their children.

The major source of their income is farming. They cultivate their farm by planting rice and vegetables twice a year. Furthermore, Alverlyn sells fruits and vegetables in their village to help her husband in gaining income. She wants to improve this small business but she had inadequate capital. That is why she wants to borrow an amount of 5,000 Philippine pesos from Kiva lenders to be used in improving her small business. She is happy and thankful because she has the opportunity to improve her small business with this financial assistance.

loans.use: Additional capital for buying and selling fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Glenita

texts.en:
She is a widow with two children: one is a policeman serving in Iligan City and the other is a college student. Mrs. Glenita M., 50 years of age, is a resident of P1 Silanga, Tangub City. As the sole breadwinner of the family, she employs herself by focusing on her sari-sari (variety) store business and is able to provide for her children’s needs.

Glenita  started her sari-sari store business eleven years ago with a starting capital of only P1,500. Now, she earns an average net income of P3,000 per month.

In 2008, Glenita joined Paglaum MPC because she was much interested in our programs and services. She was able to obtain her first loan of P5,000 and, with a good credit record, she was able to obtain multiple loans. This time, she is given the privilege of obtaining P6,000 to extend her sari-sari store and to add to her capital for purchasing the goods she needs for her business.

The future income from this loan will be used to support Glenita’s college student child and for her savings for the future needs of her family.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Myrliza's Group

texts.en:
Myrliza runs a general store selling both food and daily use products in her community. She is 33 years old, married and has two school-age children. They are from the village of Brgy. Maddiangat, Quezon, Nueva Vizcaya. Myrliza has been in her business for over three years and earns approximately 4,500 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month.

In 2009, Myrliza joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Myrliza has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI which was used to purchase products to sell. Myrliza is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offerings. This will be her second loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve the general living conditions of her family.

Myrliza P. is the leader of an eight member group accessing a loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back their loans if someone is delinquent or defaults.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Carmencita's Group

texts.en:
Carmencita R. is from the village of Quinagabian, Sta. Maria Isabela. She is 43 years old. Carmencita is the group leader of a seven-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Carmencita R.'s Group.

Carmencita is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Carmencita owns & operates a business manufacturing & selling clay products to local businesses and community members. Carmencita has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2005, Carmencita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Carmencita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from ASKI. Carmencita is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed in to manufacture her items. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay for the tuition fees for her children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed in manufacturing

loans.name: María Angélica Noyola De Alas

texts.es: María Angélica N. D. A. D. 36 años D. edad, resiD. en el departamento D. La Libertad. Vive junto a tres hijos D. 16, 12 y 9 años D. edad, los cuales se dedican a estudiar y por las tardes a ayudar a su madre con el negocio. María posee una tienda D. productos perecederos, así mismo elabora y venD. pupusas, las cuales las comercializa en las afueras D. su casa. Ella cuenta con 10 años D. poseer el negocio D. las pupusas, con el cual le ha ido muy bien ya que María posee muchos clientes los cuales en su mayoría por conocerla desD. hace muchos años, tienen la confianza D.  comprar pupusas D. muy buena calidad y sabor. María solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda contar con el dinero necesario para comprar maíz al mayoreo, así mismo queso, arroz, frijoles y chicharrón, los cuales son los ingredientes principales D. las pupusas, esto lo hace con el fin D. contar con mayor cantidad D. materia prima lo cual le servirá para ofrecer más producto y D. esta manera obtener mayores ganancias. María es madre soltera, la cual trabaja muy duro para mantener a tres hijos y brindarles todo lo que ellos necesitan, es por esto que cuenta con el deseo D. mejorar su negocio.
texts.en:
María Angélica N. D. A. is 36 years old and lives in the department of La Libertad. She lives with her three children, ages 16, 12, and 9, all of whom study, and also help their mother with her business in the afternoons. María has a perishable goods store and also makes, and sells, pupusas (filled tortillas) outsiD. her house. She has had the pupusa business for ten years and it has been going well since Maria has many customers most of whom have known her for many years. They trust that she will sell them high quality and tasty pupusas. María is asking for a loan so she can have the money to buy wholesale corn as well as cheese, rice, beans, and pork fat – the main ingredients for the pupusas. She would like to be able to count on having more prime materials to work with so she can offer more products and in this way gain more income. María is a single mother who works very hard to support her three children and give them everything they need. This is why she wants to improve her business.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy corn (wholesale), cheese, rice, beans, and pork crackling

loans.name: Natividad's Group

texts.en:
Natividad B. is a widowed woman who supports her family by operating a general store and retailing gasoline in her community. She lives in Sitio Tayap, Brgy Patag, Silay City Negros Occidental with her 5 children who are 32 to 41 years old.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since October 2003 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store and gasoline retail business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly profit of Php 5,000.

Natividad is asking for a loan of Php 29,000 so that she can sustain the working capital needs of her general store and gasoline retailing business. This will be her 15th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of Php 26,000, which she paid off well within its term was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Natividad aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well being.  

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Sharon's Group

texts.en:
Sharon E. owns a sari-sari (general) store. She sells soap, shampoo, rice, sardines and other canned goods, to generate an income to meet her needs. Sharon says: "I decided to set up a sari-sari store because I can earn enough money in this business. In 2008, I joined the CEVI microcredit program because I have a dream of constructing our own house". 
Sharon is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP from Kiva partner, Community Economic Ventures, Inc. She will use the loan to buy additional merchandise for her store.

loans.use: To buy additional merchandise

loans.name: Rossio Claudia

texts.es: La Sra. Rossio esta casada y tiene tres hijos, tiene como actividad elaboracion de tortas, galletas y masitas de reposteria, actividad que la realiza los fines de semana ya que ella tambien trabaja como secretaria de un consultorio medico; de esta manera ella puede aumentar sus ingresos y el de su familia, ya que Sr. Fernando, su esposo por el momento no vive con ellos ya que trabaja en otro lugar de Bolivia, es por esta razon que ella solicita que se le conceda un credito para poder comprar un horno mas grande y asi desarrollar mejor su actividad, por el momento ella se hace cargo de sus hijos que se encuentran en edad escolar, la Sra. Rossio es una persona responsable y trabajora que saca a su familia adelante y quiere mejorar la calidad de vida de toda su familia. Esta muy agradecida con Emprender y Kiva por la confianza brindada en la otorgacion del credito.
texts.en:
Mrs. Rossio is married and has three children. Her work is making cakes, cookies, and pastries, which she does on weekends since she also works as a receptionist at a medical office. Through these activities, she helps to augment the family’s income since Fernando, her husband, is currently working abroad outside of Bolivia. She is requesting a loan in order to buy a larger oven so she can carry out her work better. For the moment, she tends to her school-aged children on her own. Mrs. Rossio is a responsible and hard-working woman who is trying to help her family get ahead, and who wants to improve the standard of living for them all. She is very grateful to Emprender and Kiva for the confidence they show in her through the granting of credit.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For the purchase of an industrial oven.

loans.name: Cándida Rosa

texts.es:
La Señora Cándida Rosa D. H. es comerciante de este mercado desde hace 14 años que vende en su puesto de venta ella vende todo lo que es medicina natural vende piñatas que las elabora ella con la ayuda de su mamá anteriormente ella estudiaba y su mamá le administraba su negocio pero ahora ella decidio permanecer en el tramo para que la mamá descanse.
Ambas administran el negocio empezaron el negocio con un capital de C$ 8,000.00 con poco inventario  ahora su negocio es más grande mejor acondicionado ahora tengo unos cajones en donde guardo la mercadería elabora tambien piñatas, ofrenda florales, altares etc.
Sus financiamientos siempre los solicita para su negocio de los cuales saca ganancias  y es donde mejora su calidad de vida no tiene hijos que mantener pero si tiene a cargos a sus padres que ya estan señores y ella los ve.
texts.en:
Cándida Rosa D. H. has been a merchant in this market for 14 years. In her stall, she sells natural medicines and also piñatas that she makes with the help of her mother. Previously, Cándida studied while her mother tended the store, but now she has decided to run the business and let her mother rest. They both manage the business. They began with an investment of 8000 cordobas and very little inventory. Today, it is much larger, with trunks where they can store merchandise. In addition to piñatas, they make floral offerings and altars. Cándida always profits from the loans she takes out for the business. This is how she improves her quality of life. She doesn’t have children, but she is responsible for the care of her elderly parents.

Translated from Spanish by jeffrey hersk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy merchandise for store and materials for making piñatas

loans.name: Samwel Matunke

texts.en:
Samwel is a farmer and he has been doing this for the last twenty years. His farm is in a productive area and most of his customers are wholesalers from the capital city (Nairobi), who come to buy his produce and then sell to the city residents.

He learned about KADET through awareness raised by KADET staff in his area of residence. This will be his second loan which he is planning to use to buy a new species of potato called sangi which, research has proved, can do very well in his area and have more yields. He also wishes to buy ten sheep for fattening and to later sell to accumulate more capital for large scale farming.

He hopes to use the profit from this loan to acquire more land for farming to meet the demand for the farm produce. His hopes to become a large scale farmer and have his own farm machinery in future. Samwel is a hard-working man who is determined to achieve his set goals.

loans.use: To buy a new species of potato called sangi and ten sheep for fattening.

loans.name: Mauricio Javier

texts.es:
Mauricio  de 41 años de edad es casado con la Sra. Zulema Garcia con quien tiene 2 niños, Nayelis de 7 años en 2do grado de primaria y Fabricio de 3 añitos.  Mauricio trabaja en el Hospital Asuncion de Juigalpa desde hace 13 años como kardista. 

Esta solicitando su 5to Credito a esta institucion con el objetivo de mejorar su casa cambiando el techo que se encuentra en mal estado y mejorar el baño de su casa.  Expresa que con los creditos obtenidos en AFODENIC ha podido mejorar las condiciones de vida de su familia, ya que los ha utilizado en la construccion de su vivienda. 

Su mayor sueño es tener su casa con las condiciones basicas para que su familia viva en un ambiente comodo y agradable.
texts.en:
Mauricio is 41 years old. He and his wife Zulema Garcia have two children: Nayelis, age seven, who is in his second year of elementary school and three-year-old Fabricio. For thirteen years, Mauricio has been working at the Asuncion Hospital as a storage manager. Mauricio is asking for his fifth loan with AFODENIC with the goal of making improvements in his house. He would like to change the roof, which is in poor condition and make improvements to his bathroom. Mauricio says that thanks to the loans he has obtained with AFODENIC, he has been able to improve the living conditions for his family since he has used the loans to build his home. Mauricio's biggest dream is to have a house that has all the basic necessities so that his family could live in an environment that is pleasant and comfortable.

Translated from Spanish by Andrei Vazhnov, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Changing the roof and improving the bathroom

loans.name: Mugume Development Group, Lugazi

texts.en:
100,000 shillings is little enough money to survive on in a fast-driven society like the increasingly affluent Nkonkonjeru suburb in Lugazi. It’s even more hard-pressing when you have six children and two orphans to take care of. As it appears, 46-year-old M. Rebecca finds herself in such a scenario.

With her 30-year-old farming business, one would assume Rebecca earns more than what is aforementioned. That is a far cry, however, from the story of this happily married woman. The underlying reason for her low earnings is principally because she has been more of a subsistence than a commercial farmer. She has for the most part been growing and selling maize and beans on a small scale. To eke out more income, she has also been selling mineral water to add to her meager resources.

Rebecca is a diligently hardworking woman and, with this loan, she wants to buy more land to expand her farming activities. As such she wants to grow more cash crops that she will not only be able to sell in the future but also store as surplus.

loans.use: To purchase more land to expand her farming activities

loans.name: Baraka Office Group

texts.fr:
Ekanga L. est entrepreneur, vendeuse grossiste des braises, elle lève sa main sur la photo,vice présidente  du groupe de crédit Baraka Office, âgée de 42 ans, veuve, mère de  6 enfants dont tous étudient. Sa fille ainée est en première licence à l’université, et les restes sont encore à l’école secondaire et primaire. Son mari est décède vers les années 2000 suite a une longue maladie du VIH SIDA. Ekanga L. réside dans le quartier Murara, commune de Karisimbi, elle a un dépôt des braises dans le secteur Birere. En outre pour maximiser ses revenus, elle vent également d’huile de palme en gros au marché  de KIBABI. Ekanga L. a commence son business avec son fonds propres  au tour des années 2002, avant l’éruption du volcan Nyiragongo, qui avait détruit complètement la vie économique de la ville de Goma. Elle vendait des beignets, avec un capital de valeur de 12,5$. Et cela après la mort de son mari.
Vue la charge de familiale et la vie seule, elle a évolué difficilement. Cependant elle a bénéficié de premier crédit  de l’IMF Hekima en 2004. De la, elle a retrouvé un équilibre social et  économique. Dit-elle, Ekanga L. a déjà réalisé plusieurs projets familiaux (achat d’une parcelle). Si Dieu la prête vie, Ekanga L. reste ambitieuse, malgré son statut de veuve, de pouvoir construire une maison pour ses enfants. Avec  le crédit  de  l’IMF Hekima, la veuve Ekanga L.  souhaite augmenter son chiffre d’affaire en achetant 10 sacs des braises (affecte au business de braise) et 5 fus d’huile (localement appelés «Kafindondo». Ekanga L. explique le défi majeur de son activité de vente braises est lié aux multiples pillages au long de la route par des assaillants ,qui restent dans le parc national de Virunga, a l’Est de la RDC et rebelles Hutu rwandais de FDLR. A cela s’ajoute les tracasseries policières et administratives  surtout comme l’Etat a déjà pris de mesures pénales aux soit disant destructeurs de l’environnement (vendeurs de bois de parc national). Pour l’activité de vente d’huile  parfois elle achète un stock  d’huile pourries, des mauvaises qualités, qui a déjà perdue toute la saveur, étant donné que cette huile est produite en technologie locale artisanale dans la province de Kindu-Maniema et dans le grand Nord de Kivu, vers Beni, Mangina, et conservée parfois dans de bidons salles ou des emballages en caoutchouc fragile, etc.  Cela contraint à connaitre une perte énorme.
La veuve Ekanga L.  remercie l’IMF Hekima pour  les crédits  qu’elle reçoit sans aucune garantie matérielle car grâce à ces crédits, elle parvient à subvenir aux besoins de ses enfants orphelins. Le groupe baraka office est composé de 8 femmes.
texts.en:
Ekanga L. is a businesswoman who sells charcoal wholesale. She is the one raising her hand in the photo and is vice-president of the loan group Baraka Office. She is 42, a widow and mother of six children, all enrolled in school. Her eldest daughter is in the first year at university, and the others are in secondary or primary school. Her husband died after a long illness, around the year 2000, of HIV AIDS. Ekanga L. lives in the Murara neighborhood, township of Karisimbi, and she has a charcoal depot in the Birere district. Moreover, in order to maximize her income, she also sells palm oil wholesale in the market of KIBABI. Ekanga L. began her business with her own funds around 2002, before the eruption of the Nyiragongo volcano, which completely destroyed the economic life of the town of Goma. She was selling fritters with a working capital of $12.50. And all this after her husband's death. In view of her family responsibilities and living alone, she was just scraping by. However, in 2004, she received a first loan from the MFI Hekima. From then on, she was able to reestablish her social and economic equilibrium. Ekanga L. has already managed to achieve some family goals, notably the purchase of a plot of land. If God grants her long life, Ekanga L. intends to continue to be ambitious enough, despite being a widow, to build a house for her children. With the loan from Hekima, widow Ekanga L. hopes to grow her sales by buying 10 sacks of charcoal (for her charcoal business) and 5 barrels of oil (locally known as «Kafindondo».) Ekanga L. says that the major challenge to her charcoal business is the multiple attacks along the route carried out by outlaws who are hiding in the Virunga National Park, in the east of the DRC, and Rwandan Hutu rebels from the FDLR. Also the police and administrators make difficulties, especially since the State has threatened to bring to justice those they say are destroying the environment (people who sell wood from the national park). As for her oil sales business, she sometimes buys a load of spoiled oil or poor quality oil which has lost all its flavor, since this oil is produced by local artisans in the province of Kindu-Maniema and way up north near Lake Kivu, around Beni, or Mangina, and sometimes stored in dirty jerrycans or rubber containers that are fragile, etc. This can cause her an enormous loss. Widow Ekanga L. would like to thank the MFI Hekima for the loans that she receives without collateral since it is thanks to these loans that she is managing to support her orphaned children. The Baraka Office group is composed of eight women.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: 10 sacks of charcoal and 5 barrels of oil (locally known as «Kafindondo»)

loans.name: Yeni Del Carmen

texts.es:
Yeni del Carmen L. R., mujer trabajadora, esforzada y emprendedora quien es comerciante de sombreros artesanales, chinelas entre otros productos. Ella hace siete años se fue a trabajar a Costa Rica donde ahorro un dinero para luego venir a su país que tanto extrañaba a crear su negocio.

La meta de L. es tener su propio tramo ya que ella vende de manera ambulante en el mercado de Masaya.
texts.en:
Yeni del Carmen L. R. is a hardworking, enterprising woman who sells handcrafted hats and slippers, among other products. Seven years ago she went to work in Costa Rica, where she saved enough money to then return to the country she missed greatly and create her business. L.'s goal is to have her own stand at the market in Masaya.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Richardson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Handcrafts

loans.name: Nguyễn's Group

texts.en: N. Nguyễn Thị (20201030053) is a 38-year-old female living in the town of Yên Phong, Bắc Ninh. N. is the group leader of this seven-member group loan offered by SEDA. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Phố Chờ 2 nhóm 10 (Nhóm 10). N. is married and has four school-aged children. She owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling bicycles in the local community. She has been engaged in this business for over eleven years and earns approximately 3,700,000 VND a month. N. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is now requesting a new loan of 5,152,000 VND which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. The loan will be her first from SEDA. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About the other borrowers in the group: 1. Nguyễn Thị Thế (0) is a 25-year-old female who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND loan to support her butcher shop. 2. Nguyễn Thị Tư (0) is a 29-year-old female who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND loan to support her business making and selling food. 3. Nguyễn Thị T. (0) is a 23-year-old female who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND loan to support her specialized retail store. 4. Đặng Thị T. (0) is a 30-year-old female who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND loan to support her tailoring business. 5. Nghiêm Thị L. (0) is a 29-year-old female who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND loan to support her service-based business. 6. Bùi Thị H. (0) is a 33-year-old female who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND loan to support her business making and selling food. About SEDA: The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low-income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders. ***************************************************** N. Nguyễn Thị (20201030053) là 38 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh. N. là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 7 các thành viên. Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ.. Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là Phố Chờ 2 nhóm 10 (Nhóm 10). Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ bán xe đạp trong cộng đồng địa phương. N. thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 11 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, N. kiếm được khoảng 3.700.000 VND. N. đã tham gia SEDA để có thể T. cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy. 0 Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 5.152.000 VND. Khoản vay sẽ là 1st khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA. Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm: 1. Nguyễn Thị Thế (0) là 25 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hàng T.t. 2. Nguyễn Thị Tư (0) là 29 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn. 3. Nguyễn Thị T. (0) là 23 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hiệu bán lẻ chuyên dụng. 4. Đặng Thị T. (0) là 30 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh may mặc. 5. Nghiêm Thị L. (0) là 29 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh trên cơ sở dịch vụ. 6. Bùi Thị H. (0) là 33 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn. Về SEDA: Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam *Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ T. tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: Eya

texts.en: Mme. Eya A. is 38 years old and living in Lomé, Togo. She is a widow with one child. Since 1995 she’s been working at the Adidogomé Market in Lomé where she sells pagnes, a traditional Togolese wax-printed cloth, and other fabrics. She is also a seamstress who makes clothing from the fabrics she sells. As an experienced entrepreneur, she is continuously invested in strengthening and expanding her business. She is taking her third loan from WAGES of 350,000 CFA in order to purchase 25 rolls of fabric.

loans.use: To purchase pagnes and other cloth

loans.name: Celia

texts.es:
Celia, D. 55 años, es una mujer muy sencilla y trabajadora, vive en su casa propia junto a su esposo Alonso D. 65 y su hijo menor Antony D. 20 años, a quienes desea brindarles una mejor calidad D. vida. Las chacras D. Celia son las mejores cuidadas en el poblado D. Picoy, todas las mañanas, trabaja desD. muy temprano en sus tierras, ya que sabe que del cuidado que le brinD. a sus papas y alverjas dependerán los ingresos D. su familia. Lo que más le gusta D. su trabajo es la libertad que tiene para pasear por los verdes campos D. su poblado, lleva 10 años realizando esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil es cuidar sus tierras D. las plagas D. insectos. Con el tiempo, desea comprar más tierras para incrementar su producción. Este es el segundo crédito con MFP y espera ser muy puntual en sus cuotas, puesto que no quiere darle problemas a su grupo comunal, en el cual se siente muy contenta.
Con los mil nuevos soles que solicita, comprará abono para sus cultivos.
texts.en:
Celia is 55 years old. She is a very hard working, uncomplicated person. She lives in her own house together with her husband Alonso, 65, and their youngest son Antony, 20. She wants to give her family a better quality of life. The fields that Celia works are the best kept fields in the village of Picoy. Every day she works the fields from very early in the morning and she knows that the care she gives to the plantations of potatoes and peas will directly impact on the income earned for her family. What she likes best about her work is the freedom that she feels as she travels among the green fields in her village. She has been an agriculturer for the past 10 years. The hardest part about her work is keeping insect pests out of the harvest. In time she hopes to purchase more land so that she can increase her yield. This is her second loan with MFP (Kiva Field Partner). With the one thousand nuevos soles she is requesting she will invest in the purchase of fertilizer for the plantations.

Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer.

loans.name: Rosa Elvira

texts.es:
Rosa de 39 años, ella tiene una pequeña tienda en la parte delantera de su casa, vive en una zona periurbana en la Perimetral de Guayaquil. 

Ella comenzó con la tienda para poder mantener a sus tres hijos de 14, 12 y 3 años. Compro enlatados, bebidas y los vendió a sus vecino, poco a poco trabajando desde las 06h00am hasta las 22h00pm. Ahora tiene vitrinas y congeladores para sus productos. La cubeta de huevos la vende a $ 1.12, un enlatado a $ 0.90ctv, etc. 

Con el préstamo quiere comprar arroz, enlatados para su tienda, en el futuro quiere incrementar su negocio y surtir mas los productos.
texts.en:
Rosa, 39, has a small grocery store in the front part of her house. She lives in a periurban zone along Guayaquil’s Beltway. She started her store in order to support her three children who are 14, 12, and 3 years of age. She bought canned goods and beverages to sell to her neighbors little by little working from 6am until 10pm. Now, she has display cases and freezers for her products. She sells a bucket of eggs for $1.12, a canned good for 90 cents, etc. She wants the loan to buy rice and canned goods for the store. In the future she wants to increase her sales and stock more goods.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For rice and canned goods.

loans.name: Nelson Enrique

texts.es: Nelson Enrique tiene 31 años, vive con su esposa y está a cargo de 4 hijos menores de edad, los cuales se dedican a estudiar gracias al enorme esfuerzo de Nelson. Tiene un negocio de servicio de barbería, este es un negocio muy difícil pero es su única entrada de dinero lo cual ayuda su familia para salir adelante, hace mas de 7 años que se dedica a este negocio, por lo que se esfuerzan mucho día con día. El préstamo que ha sido solicitado es para poder invertir en cremas para afeitar, peines, talcos, rasuradoras eléctricas y gabachas de tela.
texts.en:
Nelson Enrique is 31 years old and lives with his wife and their four young children who are able to attend school because of his enormous efforts. He has a business where he offers his services as a barber. The work is very difficult but it is his only source of income that helps his family get ahead. Nelson has been in this business for more than seven years and works hard day after day.

The loan he is requesting will be used to buy shaving creams, combs, talcum powders, electric razors, and barber capes.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase shaving creams, combs, talcum powders, electric razors, and barber capes

loans.name: Jacqueline Elizabeth

texts.es:
Jacqueline vende arroz para poder mantener a sus dos hijos ya que es madre soltera. Ellos viven en una zona periurbana caracterizada por sus caminos de tierra es llamada “Paraíso”. 

Cuando el esposo de Jacqueline la abandono y se quedo con las deudas que tenían tubo que optar por un trabajo que le generara ingresos suficientes para poder mantener a su familia y paga las deudas, invirtió sus ahorros en sacos de arroz y los comenzó a vender a sus vecinos y conocidos. Una de sus hermanas le ayudan en la venta del arroz, trabajan desde las 11h00am.  

Para seguir con su negocio ella quiere comprar con el préstamo sacos de arroz. En el futuro quiere comprar cantidades industriales de apiladoras y ser una comerciante mayorista.
texts.en:
Jacqueline sells rice to support her two children since she’s a single mother. They live in a periurban area noted for its unpaved streets called “Paraíso.” When Jacqueline’s husband abandoned her she was left with their debts and she had to go to work at something that would generate sufficient income to support her family and pay off her debts. She invested her savings in sacks of rice and started to sell it to friends and neighbors. One of her sisters helps her with the rice sales. They start work at 11am. To continue with her business she needs a loan to buy sacks of rice. In the future, she’d like to buy industrial quantities of rice and a rice husker to become a rice wholesaler.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For rice.

loans.name: Deogratius

texts.en: Deogratius wants a loan to buy more sugar, rice and salt for reselling in his retail shop. He is married with seven children and lives in Kyenjojo, Uganda. He has a retail shop which he wants to transform into a wholesale shop. He dreams of educating his children into responsible citizens.

loans.use: Purchasing sugar, rice, cooking oil and salt for resale in his shop

loans.name: Ernalyn

texts.en:
Ernalyn D. is from the village of Hinaplanon, Baikingon, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 37 years old. Ernalyn is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Ernalyn makes and sells Filipino snack delicacies like biko and rice cakes. She also buys and sells a variety of vegetables. Ernalyn has been engaged in her business for more than three years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Ernalyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Ernalyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Ernalyn is requesting a new loan of 14000 PHP, which she will invest in expanding the business, perhaps putting up a sari-sari store. This will be the fourth loan taken by Ernalyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand the business

location.town: Baikingon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Phirum

texts.en:
Phirum C. and his wife, Sokha Kong, are vegetable farmers. They grow cucumbers and green beans. The couple has requested, received, and repaid two Kiva loans, and now Phirum is requesting another loan in the amount of $500 to purchase seed, fertilizer, and pesticides for the farming business.
  
Phirum C. and Sokha Kong were married in 1994. They have three sons and one daughter. The family lives in a village about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia.

loans.use: To purchase seed, fertilizer, and pesticides for farming

loans.name: Noun

texts.en: Noun S. is 30 years old and lives with her husband and two young children in Takeo province. She raises pigs, typically making US$1.50 of profit each day. Her husband works with his partner making and selling shoes, earning US$3 a day. Noun S. is asking for a loan of US$600 for her husband to invest with his partner for making shoes.

loans.use: To purchase shoe materials.

loans.name: Farida

texts.en:
N. Farida lives in the Makerere Kikoni neighborhood of Kampala, Uganda.  She is single and has no children. Farida sells charcoal.  She has been in this business for 4 years and she works 7 days a week. Farida sells her products retail at the market.    

Farida has requested a loan of 600,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of charcoal. Farida's main business challenge is transportation. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start selling wholesale only and to buy a plot of land.   

Farida lives in a home that she rents with electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expense is rent.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is 56 years old and is married to Leah Njeri who helps with the farm. He has a tea plantation and also a dairy farm. John has been growing tea for the past 3 years with an income of 15,000 KES per month.

This is his first loan with KADET LTD. He plans to use it to buy a dairy goat for commercial purposes. He hopes to venture into greenhouse farming and keep more dairy animals in order to train others.

loans.use: To buy a dairy goat

loans.name: Kyamazima Twimuke Group

texts.en: John is a 54-year-old ambitious married man with nine children living in a semi-permanent house in Fort Portal, Uganda. His ambition is to set up a tea estate. For 30 years, he has been selling charcoal and the business has helped him educate four of his children. His mission is to own a store and operate from one area. He is a member of Kyamazima Twimuke group, where each member guarantees the others' loans. John needs the loan to buy charcoal for resale.

loans.use: to buy charcoal

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema is married with two children, both of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are house rent and school fees.

Rehema has operated a car hire business for the past three years, passengers being her potential customers. Rehema faces a major challenge of theft in her business. She want to use this KES 40,000 loan to purchase tires to repair her cars. She decided to work with Yehu because of its good reputation in her society.She hopes to build her own home in the future.

loans.use: To purchase car tires to repair her cars for hire

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy weaving frame and materials

loans.name: Adela

texts.es: Adela tiene 54 años, es casada, tres hijos. es socia del Banco Comunal Kausachun, Tiene una tienda D. abarrotes en general en el terminal San Felipe que son buses que salen para el sur D. Ayacucho. solicita un crédito D. 1 500.00 Nuevos Soles, el cual será destinado a la compra D. mercaderias como: árroz, azúcar, fideos, leche,aguas gaseosas, etc. Adela está dos años en Finca Perú, ingreso por la invitación D. su hija,le gusta por la accesibilidad a los créditos, sobre todo pueD. ahorrar, por la capacitaciones que reciben por parte D. sus promotoras en los temas D.:la familia,matrimonio, negocios, que lo ponen en práctica en su vida diaria.
texts.en:
Adela, 54, is married and has three children.   She’s a member of the Kausachun communal bank.  She has a grocery store at the San Felipe bus terminal for buses going to the south of Ayacucho.

She is asking for a 1500 new sol loan to buy merchandise like: rice, sugar, noodles, milk, soft drinks, etc.

Adela has been in Finca Perú for two years.  Her daughter invited her to join.  She likes it because of the accessibility of loans, above all because she can save, and for the training they get from their advisor on topics like: family, marriage and business that they can put into practice in their daily lives.

loans.use: To buy stock items for her store.

loans.name: Mony

texts.en:
Mrs. Mony N. and her husband, Mr. Moeurn Chea, have been married since 1985.  They have four children -- two sons and two daughters. One is married, one is a garment factory worker and other two are in school. The couple lives along the Tonle Basac River, a tributary of the nearby Mekong River, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penn City.

Mony is a flower farmer.  She also buys bananas in her village and transports both flowers and bananas to sell at the Phnom Penh market. A recipient of a previous Kiva loan, she is now requesting another loan of $1,200 to organize her house by laying bricks in order to visually enhance it.

loans.use: To organize her house by laying bricks in order to visually enhance it.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more provisions and drinks.

loans.name: Kadyrzhan

texts.ru:
Кадыржану Омуралиеву 52 года, женат и является отцом шести дочерей.
Кадыржан родился в простой и многодетной семье фермера и с детства помогал отцу по хозяйству. После окончания школы, Кадыржан поступил на учебу в автошколу  и устроился в родном колхозе на работу в качестве водителя грузовых автомашин. В 1985 году в возрасте 26 лет Кадыржан женился и спустя два года у него родилась дочь. В этом же году колхоз, в котором он работал, выделил ему небольшой участок в родном селе, где он построил дом и сараи, и стал содержать небольшое хозяйство. С годами семья Кадыржана росла, и росли потребности - зарплаты шофера не хватало, и Кадыржан решил полностью посвятить свое время разведению скота. В 2010 году Кадыржан выдал старшую дочку замуж и для того, чтобы по всем обычаям, включая подготовку хорошего приданного, провести свадьбу, ему пришлось продать две дойных коровы и одного бычка. На данный момент, в хозяйстве у Кадыржана осталась лишь одна дойная корова, и поэтому он обратился за кредитом в сумме 100,000 сом (KGS) на покупку дойной коровы, овец и бычков. В планах у Кадыржана - расширение площади сарая и увеличение поголовья скота.
ЗАО МФК "Бай-Тушум и Партнеры" предоставляет кредиты по линии Кива для социально-уязвимых слоев населения. ЗАО МФК "Бай-Тушум и Партнеры" является одной из лидирующих Микрофинансовых организаций Кыргызстана. "Бай-Тушум и Партнеры" – это надежный финансовый партнер, осуществляющий вклад в развитие экономики Кыргызской Республики путем предоставления доступных микрофинансовых услуг в сельской местности и городах, способствующих созданию рабочих мест и отвечающий интересам своих клиентов и инвесторов.
texts.en:
Kadyrzhan O. is 52 years old, married, and is the father of six daughters.

Kadyrzhan was born into a large, simple farm family, and since childhood he helped his father on the farm.  After leaving school, Kadyrzhan went to driving school and got a job at his home collective farm driving cargo. In 1985 when he was 26 years old, Kadyrzhan married, and two years later his daughter was born. That same year the collective farm where he worked allocated to him a small plot of land in his home village where he constructed a house and sheds, and began a small farm. Over time, Kadyrzhan’s family grew, as did their expenses.  His salary as a driver was no longer enough.  Kadyrzhan decided to devote all of his time to raising cattle.  In 2010 Kadyrzhan married off his eldest daughter, and to pay for a traditional wedding, he had to sell two milk cows and one calf. Now on his farm, Kadyrzhan has only one milk cow.  Consequently he is asking for a loan for 100,000 som (KGS) to buy a milk cow, sheep, and calves. Kadyrzhan plans to expand his barn and increase his livestock.

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Alberto's Group

texts.en:
Alberto R. is from the village of Bacnor East. He is 33 years old. Alberto is the leader of a five-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Alberto R.'s Group.

Alberto is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Alberto makes and sells food, primarily barbecue pork and chicken. Alberto has been engaged in his business for over 11 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

In 2011, Alberto joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his business and living situation. Alberto is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Alberto from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand his business. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Nicholas

texts.en: Nicholas is 34 years old and married with two children.  He does printing and photocopying to earn a living.  Nicholas has been in this business for ten years and has one employee.  Since he joined Faulu Kenya, his business has improved and, hence, so has his living standard.  He hopes to have a stable business in the future.  He has requested a loan of 80,000 KES to buy printing papers.

loans.use: To buy printing papers.

loans.name: Catherine

texts.fr: Catherine est née en 1979 au Gabon, pays voisin du Bénin. Catherine a trois enfants, tous scolarisés, avec lesquels elle vit. En effet, il y a près de sept ans que Catherine s’est installée à PK11 dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji. Catherine ne vit plus avec son mari. Afin de subvenir à ses besoins et de répondre aux besoins de ses enfants, Catherine prépare de la nourriture (pâte de maïs, riz, accompagné de sauce) au Parcs de Mivvo dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji. De façon secondaire, Catherine vend des cartes de recharges téléphoniques. Catherine achète ses produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C’est la quatrième fois que Catherine sollicite auprès d’ALIDé, un crédit en vue de renforcer son capital et d’élever le niveau de son activité.
texts.en: Catherine was born in 1979 in Gabon, a neighboring country to Benin. She has three children who live with her and all of them are at school. Almost seven years ago Catherine settled down in PK11 in the municipality of Sèmè-Podji. Catherine no longer lives with her husband. In order to provide for her needs and those of her children, she makes food (corn paste and rice accompanied by sauces) at Parcs de Miwo in the municipality of Sèmè-Podji. As a secondary activity, Catherine sells telephone recharge cards. She buys her products at Dantokpa, Benin's international market. It is the fourth time that Catherine has requested a loan from Alidé, and this loan will be used to strengthen her capital and expand her business.

loans.use: to buy sacks of corn and rice, as well as condiments for sauces

loans.name: Djekafo Group

texts.fr:
Djekafo est un regroupement de quatre femmes mariées qui ont en moyenne 49 ans, 5 enfants et  qui vivent dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans la ville de Fana, préfecture de Dioïla, Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce de fruits, de condiments alimentaires et d’habits.                                                                                                                          
Les femmes du groupe Djekafo sont à leur onzième prêt solidaire et les dix précédents ont tous été remboursés sans aucune difficulté.                                                                        
La cliente AWA compte acheter des fruits et des tubercules avec les revendeurs du marché de Fana. Elle effectue ses ventes sur place dans la ville de Fana au bord du goudron, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 25 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt, payer les contributions des cérémonies sociales et le reste sera  réinvesti dans son activité.
texts.en:
Djekafo is a group of four married women who have an average age of 49 and, on average, five children, and who live in traditional extended families in the town of Fana, prefecture of Dioïla, Koulikoro Region (second administrative region of the Republic of Mali). 

They came to know each other through being related, or as neighbors or friends. They sell fruit, condiments, and clothing. They are on their 11th solidarity loan, and the ten preceding ones were reimbursed with no difficulty. 
                                                                        
Our client by the name of Awa intends to buy fruit and yams from the sellers at the market of Fana. She resells her merchandise right in Fana along the highway, for cash or credit, to a clientele composed of men and women. She expects to make an average monthly profit of 25,000 F CFA which will be used to make payments on the loan and to pay her share of social ceremonies, with the rest being invested in her business.

loans.use: to buy fruit and yams.

loans.name: 14 De Junio Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “14 DE JUNIO” iniciará su primer ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del centro focal Alto Lima, está compuesta por ocho integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva encabezada por la señora Aurora. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos tenemos: costura de polleras, venta de frutas, venta de comida, venta de refrescos, venta de ropa interior, venta de coca, venta de arroz.

La señora Aurora, indica que es la primera vez  que trabaja en Pro Mujer y que ingreso por invitación de la promotora. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de costura de polleras, que viene trabajando hace once años atrás,  aprendiendo el mismo de su tía que antiguamente realizaba esta actividad.
 
El crédito que ahora sacará es para la compra tela (aumentar capital). Este producto los comprará por mayor de la calle Max Paredez, posteriormente cuando ya estén elaborados los productos los venderá a pedido en diferentes tiendas. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para apoyar a su familia, pues ella es casada y tiene dos hijos.
texts.en:
The group "14 de Julio" will begin their first cycle with Pro Mujer, as part of the focal center Alto Lima. The group has 8 members and a board of directors headed by Aurora. The members have varied businesses including making traditional skirts, selling fruit, selling food, selling sodas, underwear sales, coca leaf sales and selling rice. 

Aurora says this is the first time that she has worked with Pro Mujer and that she joined at the invitation of the promoter. Currently she has a business sewing traditional Andean skirts. She has been doing this for 11 years, learning from her aunt who used to do the same thing.

The loan that she will take out now is to buy fabric (increase capital). She will buy the fabric in bulk on Max Paradez street. Once the skirts are made she will sell them by request to different stores. This work allows her to generate income to support her family, since she is married and has two children.

loans.use: to buy fabric.

loans.name: Komlan

texts.fr: Jeune homme de 39ans, Komlan aime rendre belle toute personne. Il a ouvert  en 1999 son salon de couture et en même temps vend des produits de mercerie et des habits cousus. Il est papa de 02 enfants et sa femme est revendeuse. Il sollicite ce prêt pour acheter des produits de mercerie. Il a une ambition devenir un couturier de renom.
texts.en: A young man aged 39, Komlan likes making everyone beautiful. He opened his dressmaking shop in 1999, and at the same time has been selling haberdashery items and sewn clothing. He is the father of two children and his wife is a retailer. He is seeking this loan to buy haberdashery goods. His ambition is to become a well-known designer.

loans.use: To buy fabric and pagnes (a type of West African cloth).

loans.name: Sop Mame Awa Balla Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité Sop Mame Awa Balla du Banc Villageois Sop Borom Darou Mousty est créé depuis le 10 décembre 2010,il est composé de dix sept femmes qui sont toutes parentes et le petit commerce (d'habits,parfums,bijoux) est leur activité principale; elles font aussi de l'élevage.

Madame Coumba la responsable est âgée de 41 ans, elle es mariée sans enfant mais a en charge ses trois nièces et un neveu;elle mène comme activité principale l'embouche ovine et a une bonne expérience. Sur la photo elle est debout à droite et est habillée en bleu.

Elle achète ses moutons dans les marchés hebdomadaires, les élèvent et les revend à l'approche du recouvrement.

Son prêt lui permettra d'acheter des moutons pour l'embouche et des aliments de bétail.

Ses bénéfices lui permettent de renforcer son épargne et d'aider son mari pour le bien être de la famille.
texts.en:
The Sop Mama Awa Balla community group from the Sop Borome Darou Mousty village bank was formed on the 10th December 2010. The group is made up of seventeen women who are all related, and whose main line of trade is in clothes, perfume and jewellery. They are also involved in the rearing of animals. 

Madame Coumba is the group leader and is 41 years old and married. She has no children of her own, but looks after her three nieces and one nephew. Her main line of trade is in rearing animals, where she has considerable experience. She is standing on the right hand side in the photo, wearing blue. 

She buys her sheep from the weekly market, rears them and then sells them on.  This loan will enable her to purchase sheep for rearing, and cattle feed. The profits she generates will enable her to boost her savings and help her husband to see to the family's well-being.

loans.use: to purchase sheep for rearing and sale

loans.name: Lanie Marie

texts.en:
Lanie Marie is 52 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with three children. 

Lanie Marie has an internet cafe shop that provides encoding & online games. She has had this business for two years. She requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy tools & pay for the utilities for the computer services.

Lanie Marie is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Lanie Marie hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy tools & pay for the utilities for computer services

loans.name: Elva Silvana

texts.es:
Elva tiene 27 años vive en Tulcán con su hijo de 1 año, es soltera, se describe como una persona alegre, colaboradora y le gusta ser amigable.

Trabaja en la crianza de cerdos sola desde hace 5 años, le va muy bien en su trabajo.

Es la primera vez que trabaja con FODEMI, con el crédito que solicita piensa comprar más cerdos para seguir en la crianza, con este préstamo su negocio cambiaría ya que aumentarían las ventas y tendría una mejor calidad de vida junto a su hijo, su anhelo es ver crecer con mucha salud a su hijo y ver que su negocio crezca.
texts.en:
Elva is 27 years old, lives in Tulcán with her 1 year old son, and is single. She describes herself as being cheerful, cooperative, and likes to be friendly.

For 5 years she has been raising and selling pigs and is doing very well with her business.

This is the first time she works with FODEMI. She plans on using the loan to buy more pigs to raise. This loan will help her make more sales and allow her to have a better quality of life with her son. Her desire is to watch her son grow with health and watch her business grow.

loans.use: buy more pigs.

loans.name: Geraldine

texts.en:
Geraldine, age 28, runs a general store to earn her living. She has been engaged in this business for two years. Each month, she earns PHP 5,000.00. She has requested a loan for PHP 8,000 in order to purchase more products to stock in her general store. Geraldine and her husband have three children and the family lives in Ibabao, Siquijior, Siquijor.

Geraldine has been a member of Paglaum Multi Purpose Cooperative for five months. She hopes to pay off her installments on her motorcycle in the near future as a resuklt of the increase in income of her business.

loans.use: to purchase more products to stock in her general store

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy artificial jewelry and beads for making & selling jewelry

loans.name: Marisil

texts.en:
Marisil is 26 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married, with 3 children. Marisil has a shop that sells used clothing or ukay-ukay. She has had this business for 3 years.
