En estos momentos el negocio de venta de abarrotes del señor G. atraviesa la necesidad de ser suplido con mercadería para ofertarla y por esta razón él no duda en acudir a Ceprodel para obtener el crédito para la compra de los productos para su respectiva comercialización.
texts.en:
Roberto G. owns his own business selling groceries in the district of Chichigalpa in the city of Chinandega. Since he has had the business he has managed to earn a living, improving living conditions for his family. For this reason, he works hard at his business. Lately, Roberto's business of selling groceries faces the need to be supplied with merchandise to be sold. For this reason, he has no doubts in turning to Ceprodel to obtain a loan to buy the products that he will then sell.

Translated from Spanish by Anne Rodriguez, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy basic goods

loans.name: Safia Parveen M.ramzan Group

texts.en:
Safia parveen baji is a 33 year old lady who resides in a city named Borewala in Pakistan. She owns a two room brick house and has been living in it for the past 18 years. Naseem baji couldn’t get an education because of her poor financial condition. She got married at the age of 20. Her husband's name is M. and he has a grocery shop. Most of the people in the community come to him to buy groceries. Safia baji has four children: two sons and two daughters. All of her children are getting an education. Safia baji and Mr.Ramzan decided to share the expenses. Safia baji sews clothes and makes embroidered dresses and uses the profit to pay her children’s school fees and Mr. Ramzan bears the house expenses. She is applying for a loan to buy groceries for her husband’s grocery shop.

Safia baji is the leader of a group with a few more members. Razia baji wants a loan to buy wires and switch boards for her electric shop. Zubaida baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Fozia baji wants a loan to buy repair tools for her motor workshop. Tahira yasmeen baji wants a loan to buy sanitary supplies (water pipes) to resell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to sell in the grocery shop.

loans.name: Guillermina

texts.es:
La señora Guillermina S. Z. esta separada de su esposo, tiene una hija pequeña, ella tiene un negocio de venta de artículos eléctricos llamado “venta de televisores usados” el cual es atendido por ella y le proporciona ingresos los cuales son necesarios para mantener a su hija, además recibe otros ingresos por concepto de pensión alimenticia por parte de su ex-esposo.
La señora Guillermina S. está solicitando un préstamo para comprar un lote de televisores para la venta o para vender las partes de estas mismas a los talleres eléctricos como refacciones usadas.
texts.en:
Mrs. Guillermina S. Z. is separated from her husband, has a small daughter and has her own electronics business which helps her support herself and her daughter. She sells used televisions as a way of living and also gets alimony from her ex-husband.

Mrs. Guillermina S. Z. is requesting a loan in order to purchase more used televisions. She will use these to sell their parts.


Translated from Spanish by Maria Peterson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of televisions for parts

loans.name: Claire

texts.fr: Claire A. est propriétaire d’un magasin d’alimentation général, depuis 7 ans, dans un quartier populaire de Lomé. Agée de 39 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 3 enfants. Elle souhaite accroître la taille de son commerce en alimentant son magasin. Les revenus qui seront issus de ses ventes lui permettront de mieux subvenir aux besoins de ses enfants
texts.en:
For 7 years, Claire A., 39, has been the proprietor of a general store in a working class neighborhood of Lomé. She is married and the mother of 3 children. She would like to grow the size of her business by replenishing her inventory. The income from her sales allows her to better cater for the needs of her children.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: replenish her inventory

loans.name: Dan

texts.en: S. is 52 years old and a resident of Banteay Meanchey, Cambodia. He has six children: one is married and lives separately; two work in Phnom Penh, a city in Cambodia; and the rest are attending school. S. is married to Dy, 45, who earns a living by selling junk food through the commune. S. has been a motor taxi driver since 1990. He is known for being a very innocent person and a struggling father. He gets up early every morning to take his customers to work and he takes them back in the late afternoon. He has a net income of $5 per day. S. recently faced some difficulty when his son needed transportation for his job. So S. is applying for a loan of $800 to buy a motorbike for his son and his family. The loan will help the family attain a better standard of living.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for his son and family

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia D. sells rice. She is 47 years old and owns a small farm that she has been tilling for 20 years. She married a farmer, Florentino D., Jr., and they have four children who attend school. School is quite expensive nowadays, so she and her husband work very hard to pay for the tuition, books and other miscellaneous school fees.

She is asking for a loan to buy six bags of urea fertilizer and rice seed. The loan will truly help her to achieve a better yield in her farm. In this way, she believes, she will have more rice to sell to support her family.

CEVI helps farmers to increase the size of their farm produce. CEVI clients are given not just credit, but training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To buy six bags or urea fertilizer and rice seed

loans.name: Adoudé

texts.fr: Madame A. Adoudé est née le 29 02 1968 à  Aneho. Elle est mariée et a trois personnes à charges. N’ayant pas fait les études elle s’est lancée dans le commerce depuis son adolescence. Mais par manque de moyens financiers elle n’arrive pas à faire son commerce convenablement depuis quelques temps. Dans le souci de relancer ses activités et développer commerce, elle sollicite ce crédit pour achat et vente de  pagnes, bijoux et de friperie. Des revenus issus de ce commerce lui permettront de satisfaire  ses besoins.
texts.en:
Ms. A. Adoudé was born on February 29, 1968 in Aneho. She is married and has three people to look after. Not having gone to school, she got started in commerce as an adolescent. But due to a lack of financial means, she has not been able to operate her business properly for sometime now. Wanting to reinvigorate her work and to develop her commerce, she’s requesting this loan to buy and sell pagnes (colorful West African cloth), jewelry, and second-hand clothing. The revenues derived from her commerce will enable her to meet her needs.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and sell cloth, jewelry, and second-hand clothing

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma L., 61, is the mother of two children, both of whom have completed college. They live in Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. In order to earn income, she and her husband make and sell pancakes, a business that allowed them to send their children to school.

Recently, Norma decided to establish a little "sari-sari" (variety) store, the income from which she feels will meet their daily needs and reduce their workload now that they are approaching old age.

loans.use: Additional capital to buy supplies for the sari-sari store.

loans.name: Julia

texts.en:
Julia is 29 years old, married and lives in the village of Barangay Natappian West Solana, Cagayan, where she operates a small general store. This business is her sole source of income, and her husband helps her run it. Working together, they hope to provide a good future for their children. To help generate additional income, her husband sometimes works as hired farm laborer. 

Julia works at her job while also doing household chores, and finds it difficult to expand her business because money is so tight. She is seeking this loan to improve her store, increase her income, and improve her house.

loans.use: To expand her small grocery store

loans.name: Juan Pablo

texts.es:
Juan Pablo P. es una joven de 22 años de edad. Vive con sus padres y sus cuatro hermanos, en una comunidad rural de Costa Rica llamada Mollejones de Platanares, Pérez Zeledón. Mollejones es una comunidad ubicada a 150 kilómetros al sur de la Provincia de San José, la capital de Costa Rica. Se encuentra a 850 metros  sobre el nivel del mar. Ahí se cultivan hortalizas, café y además se desarrollan otras actividades como la crianza de ganado de engorde y de cerdos. Existen también algunos proyectos de agricultura orgánica y hortalizas en hidroponía. Además de la agricultura en la comunidad hay talleres mecánicos, un supermercado, pequeños restaurantes (sodas) y una mueblería.

Juan  Pablo trabaja en la Fuerza Pública en Dominical de Osa como policía; comenta que su trabajo está muy lejos de su casa y que se le dificulta la manera de llegar hasta él, ya que los caminos no están en muy buen estado y además hay muy poco transporte público. 

Por lo cual Juan Pablo ha decidido comprar una moto para poder transportarse mejor y así agilizar  la forma en la que viaja y poder ahorrar y aprovechar más  el tiempo. Por lo tanto requiere un préstamo de ¢300.000 (trescientos mil colones) para comprar la moto y así poder tener un vehículo propio que le permita seguir adelante  y facilitarle su modo de viajar.

Juan Pablo forma parte de la Empresa de Crédito Comunal de Bancruce, una de las 100 organizaciones socias de EDESA en Costa Rica. Este será su primer préstamo pero Juan Pablo  destaca que gracias a este tipo de organizaciones y medios facilitadores de crédito puede dedicar más tiempo a las actividades productivas.
texts.en:
JJuan Pablo P. is a young, 22-year old man. He lives with his parents and his four siblings in the rural Costa Rican community of Mollejones de Platanares, Pérez Zeledón. Mollejones is a community located 150 kilometers south of the province of San José, the capital of Costa Rica, and is 850 meters above sea level. In this area, people grow vegetables, coffee, and also carry out activities related to raising livestock and pigs. There also exist several projects related to organic farming and hydroponics (a technique of growing plants, without soil, in nutrient-rich water). In addition to the agricultural pursuits of the area, there are also auto repair shops, a supermarket, small restaurants (sodas) and a furniture store. Juan Pablo works as an officer for the State Police force; he comments that his work is very far from his home, and it is difficult for him to travel there as the roads are in disrepair and there is little access to public transportation. For this reason, Juan has decided to buy a motorcycle in order to be able to travel to work. It will also help him save time and money. He needs a loan of 300,000 Costa Rican colones ($550USD) to buy a motorcyle. Having his own vehicle as his primary mode of transportation will allow him to continue to progress. Juan Pablo is part of the Empresa de Crédito Comunal de Bancruce, one of the 100 member organizations of EDESA in Costa Rica. This will be his first loan but Juan Pablo stresses that, thanks to these types of organizations and credit facilitators, he can dedicate more time to activities that are productive.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle.

loans.name: Virgen Santísima Group

texts.es:
El banco Comunal Virgen Santísima se encuentra ubicado en L. Comunidad D. Ccachuana Millpu, distrito D. Asención, provincia D. Huancavelica. Esta Comunidad,se dedica al comercio, siendo su principal plaza L. ciudad D. Huancavelica, ubicada a 02 Kilómetros D. distancia.

Flora,  es casada y tiene 04 hijos. ElL. se dedica a L. venta D. carnes D. alpacas y carneros, negocio que inicio su esposo y ahora elL. dirige y financia con los prestamos que recibe. Se encuentra ahorrando para pagar los estudios D. sus hijos.

Regina, se dedica a L. venta D. abarrotes, ahora cuenta con un local propio, ya que antes alquilaba uno. ElL. quiere invertir su préstamo para surtir mercadería,  así como comprar vitrinas para L. exhibición D. sus productos. ElL. tiene un hijo D. 17 años, que es por quien lucha y ahorra para costear sus estudios.

Elizabeth se inicio en el negocio D. L. venta D. abarrotes, para obtener mas ingresos familiares y D. esa manera ayudar a su esposo, quien se dedica al negocio del calzado. ElL. con cada préstamo abastece su tienda, así como el negocio D. su esposo. Actualmente esta ahorrando para mejorar su tienda y comprar una maquina D. coser para L. zapatería.
texts.en:
The Virgen Santísima Community Bank is located in the Ccachuana Millpu community, Asención district, Huancavelica province. This community works in commerce as the main market in the city of Huancavelica is two kilometers away. Flor is married and has four children. She sells alpaca meat and lamb. Her husband started the business and now she runs it. She finances it with the loans she receives. She is saving to pay for her children’s studies. Regina sells groceries. She now has her own place; before she rented one. She wants to use her loan to stock merchandise. She will buy display cases to show her products. She has a 17 year old son. She struggles for him, and she saves to pay for his studies. Elizabeth started her business of selling groceries to obtain more family income and help her husband who is in the footwear business. With every loan she stocks her store and her husband’s business. She is currently saving to improve her store and buy a sewing machine for the shoe shop.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Stock their businesses and buy merchandise

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To grow yams

loans.name: Zensontles Group

texts.es:
El grupo Zensontle lo conforman tres mujeres beligerantes, trabajadoras, con visión  y muy capaces estas son Paula del Carmen Rodríguez C.,  María Félix Hernández P. y  María del Rosario G..  Ellas provienen de la comarca Cofradía una zona rural de muy difícil acceso de Nindiri.

Este grupo tiene varios ciclos trabajando en conjunto con Adim lo cual poco a poco les ayudado mejorar sus negocios y su calidad de vida. Actualmente los negocios de cada una de ellas van prosperando pero requieren de mayor inversión de capital con el que  no cuentan, es por esta razón que han decidido renovar su préstamo y seguir adelante.

La coordinadora del grupo es la señora Paula del Carmen Rodríguez de 38 años de edad  que desde hace cuatro años empezó vendiendo productos de belleza de la marca Avon en una empresa  en la cual trabajaba; para así poder ayudarse en la manutención de sus cuatro hijos de las edades 13, 17, 18 y 20 años respectivamente.

 El negocio  con el pasar del tiempo  y con los créditos que le brindo adim  fue creciendo de tal manera  que ella es distribuidora de  sus productos. Su otra compañera es María del Rosario G. que también vende cosméticos pero de otro tipo más comercial y accesible  como champú, desorante, cremas, pinturas y tintes entre otros. Esta señora tiene cinco hijos de los cuales cuatro dependen de ella que tienen las edades de 17, 15, 11 y 9 años respectivamente. 

La otra integrante del grupo es María Félix Hernández P. madre de cuatro hijo entre las edades de 2, 9, 20 y 22 años por los cuales ella hace cualquier sacrificio. El negocio de ella es la comercialización de postres tradicionales como son la cosa de horno (perreque, torta de leche, casualitas), cajeta (de leche, coco, coyolito, maní) y pozol. Este tipo de trabajo requiere de mucho esfuerzo e inversión por los ingredientes como leche, dulce, leña, las frutas, maíz y cuajada y lo difícil de su preparación.
texts.en:
The Zensontle Group consists of three hard-working women with vision and ability: Paula del Carmen Rodríguez C., María Félix Hernández P. and María del Rosario G.. They come from the Cofradía region, a remote rural area of Nindiri. This group has several loan cycles with ADIM which little by little has helped them improve their businesses and their quality of life. Today each of their businesses are prospering but they need an inversion of capital that they don’t have, so they have decided to renew their loan and continue forward. The coordinator of the group is 38 year old Paula del Carmen Rodríguez who has been selling Avon beauty products for 4 years in a business where she used to work. She sells so she can help support her four children ages 13, 17, 18, and 20. Over time and with the loans provided by ADIM the business has grown so much that she is a distributor of her products. Her other colleague is María del Rosario G. who also sells cosmetics but of another brand more widely sold including shampoo, deodorant, moisturizers, makeup, coloring and more. This woman has 5 children, 4 of which still depend upon her and are ages 17, 15, 11, and 9 years old. The other member of the group is María Félix Hernández P., mother of 4 children ages 2, 9, 20, and 22 years old for whom she would make any sacrifice. She sells traditional desserts such as baked goods (milk cake, pastries), caramel (milk caramel, coconut, peanut), and pozol (a corn masa drink). This type of work requires great effort and investment because of the ingredients such as milk, sweetener, wood, fruit, corn, curd and for the difficulty in their preparation.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy products such as makeup, shampoo, moisturizers, perfume, etc.

loans.name: Houda

texts.en:
Houda has been working as a hairdresser. Houda is outstanding in her work because she knows how to treat her clients and is aware of new hairstyles. Her clients are her friends and neighbors. When she first started her business, she didn’t have startup capital. She decided on this business to take advantage of her experience. 

Houda is a 45-year-old woman who lives in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon, with her husband and their four children. She requested a loan of $1700 US from Al Majmoua in order to purchase new tools for her work. This is her second loan cycle and she has always repaid on time. In the future, she plans on expanding her business.

loans.use: To purchase new tools for her salon

loans.name: Fatou

texts.fr: Fatou T. est une femme de 52 ans, veuve et mère de 9 enfants. Elle s’active dans l’embauche bovine et ovine. En même temps aussi elle fait de la transformation en huile de l’arachide. Elle aimerait renforcer son activité pour mieux prendre en charge sa famille.
texts.en:
Fatou T. is a 52-year-old woman, a widow, and the mother of nine children. She is active in fattening cattle and sheep. At the same time, she also processes peanuts for the oil. She would like to bolster her business to support her family better.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Fatou THIAW est une femme de 52 ans, veuve et mère de 9 enfants. Elle s’active dans l’embauche bovine et ovine. En même temps aussi elle fait de la transformation en huile de l’arachide. Elle aimerait renforcer son activité pour mieux prendre en charge sa famille.	Fatou THIAW is a 52-year-old woman, a widow, and the mother of nine children.  She is active in fattening cattle and sheep.  At the same time, she also processes peanuts for the oil.  She would like to bolster her business to support her family better.  Faire de l'embauche bovine et ovine et de la transformation de l'arachide en huile To fatten cattle and sheep and to process peanuts for oil

loans.name: Fe

texts.en:
Fe C. is a retailer in the village of Barangcuag Angadana, Isabela. She is already 29 years of age, married to Joselito C. who is working in a certain construction site near their place. They are already blessed with a child and he is now in his third year high school. They are 3 family members living peacefully in their village of Barangcuag of which it is a rural and plain area, along the town highway.
Her store is doing well though it was just started over the past two months. She is asking for additional business capital in order to further improve the business and earn a bigger income for her family. Weekly, Fe is able to earn around PHP2, 500 gross income, the income is being revolved for the maintenance of the business while some of which is being used as daily allowances of her child in school. She hopes to avail the amount of PHP5, 000 as added capital to her general store business development

loans.use: additional business capital

loans.name: Akossiwavi Thérèse

texts.fr: Cette dame est mariée à un professeur de collège ; grâce à l’aide de son mari, elle a pu ouvrir en 2003 dans le quartier de Baguida à Lomé une boutique d’alimentation générale. Elle est spécialisée dans la vente de vins, de boissons alcoolisées de qualité, des cannettes, d’eau minérale et de confitures. Elle réalise de très bonnes affaires après une longue expérience acquise dans le quartier. Elle vend ses produits en gros et en détail ; elle est fière de ce commerce qui lui permet entre autres de satisfaire à la plupart de ses besoins et d’aider aussi financièrement son mari dans la gestion du foyer. Elle compte en ce moment renouveler son stock en baisse ; c’est pour cette raison qu’elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour commandes 12 cartons de boissons en cannettes, 15 cartons d’eau minérale, 10 cartons de vins, 15 cartons d’huiles raffinées et des boîtes de confiture. Elle est mère d’un enfant.

loans.use: Achats des produits d'alimentation générale

loans.name: Zultai

texts.en:
Zultai B. is 33 years old and lives with his wife and two sons in Bayan-Ulgii province in western Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian housing tent. His wife works as a cook and has a monthly salary of 60,000 tugrugs (~42 USD). B.'s oldest son attends a local secondary school and his youngest is in kindergarten. 

B. currently operates a taxi service in his town. He first went into business in 2001 by transporting and delivering coal and firewood using his own truck. However, in 2006 the truck broke down and B. decided to buy a small car to transport people instead. He has found some success with his taxi, however, as many people in his town have started driving taxis in recent years, his profits have been decreasing. B. hasn't given up on his truck and hopes to make repairs and restart his transport business. 

B. is a very hardworking man who works every day until midnight. Although his profits aren't what they used to be, his earnings have enabled him to build a house for his family. For the future, he says, "I am trying hard to earn enough money to help my wife open a cafe." B. is requesting a 600,000 tugrug loan to purchase parts to repair his truck and some coal and firewood to sell.

loans.use: To repair his truck and buy some coal and firewood to sell

loans.name: Antonio Luis

texts.es: El señor Antonio vive con su esposa la SrA. Asunta, y sus hijos de 17 y 15 años. Viven en anticrético en la zona de Huayra Kasa. Los clientes se dedican a prestar servicios de pintado de interiores y exteriores. El señor Antonio trabaja por su parte en dicho rubro y la señora al haber aprendido la actividad realiza sus propios contratos de manera independiente. Son muy cotizados en su rubro. Pese a que en esta actividad tienen bastante competencia, ellos son bastante cotizados en su rubro y tienen buena clientela que contactan a través de tienda de venta de pinturas. El crédito fue destinado para algunos gastos de consumo, por las fiestas de TODOS LOS SANTOS (día de los muertos). El Sr. Antonio trabaja desde hace mucho tiempo con nuestra institución y es considerado buen cliente ya que realiza sus pagos puntualmente.
texts.en:
Sr. Antonio lives with his wife, Sra. Asunta, and their two children (ages 17 and 15). They live in a rental property in the district of Huayra Kasa. These clients provide interior and exterior painting services. Sr. Antonio does the actual painting while his wife manages the business activities since he works as an independent contractor. Their services are in great demand in the area. Although there is significant competition, their services are fairly priced and they have a good clientele who contact them whenever they need rooms painted.

This loan will be used to pay for some consumer expenses related to the All Saints Day festivals (Día de los Muertos, or Day of the Dead). Sr. Antonio has been with our Institution for a long time and is considered a good client who has been punctual with his payments.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Consumer expenses

loans.name: Teriya Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Teriya sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne  d’âge de 40 ans et 4 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans la ville de Dioïla, préfecture de Dioïla, Région de Koulikoro, République du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues par des liens de voisinage et de parentés. 
Elles exercent le commerce d’articles divers. Ces femmes ont intégrés  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pérenniser leurs activités lucratives. 
Elles sont à leur dixième prêt de groupe et tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Avec ce  nouveau prêt elles comptent acheter, une grande quantité de fruits et des habits. Les habillements sont achetés à Bamako, les fruits sont achetés sur place et dans les villages environnants. Elles vendent sur place à Dioïla à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.  
Elles envisagent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 49 900FCFA par personne. Les bénéfices sont d’une part réinvestis dans l’activité et d’autre part dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The members of Teriya group are married women with an average age of 40 and 4 children. With their husband and children they live in large traditional families in the town of Dioïla in the prefecture of Dioïla, which lies in the region of Koulikoro in the Republic of Mali. They got to know each other through neighbours and relatives. They trade various products. These women have joined the microfinance company Soro Yiriwaso with the aim of sustaining their profitable business. They are on their tenth group loan and all their previous loans have been repaid punctually. With this new loan they are planning to buy a large quantity of fruit and clothes. They buy the clothes in Barnako and the fruits both locally and in surrounding villages. They sell locally in Dioïla to both male and female customers. They estimate that they will make a monthly profit of 49,900FCFA per person. A part of the profits is reinvested in the business while part is used for the family's daily expenses.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of clothes and fruit

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional phone accesories for her business.

loans.name: Myrna's Group

texts.en: Myrna R. is from the village of Sta.Cruz, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 39 years old. Myrna is the group leader of a five-member group loan offered by ASKI, a Kiva partner. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Sta. Cruz Center. Myrna is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Myrna raises livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs to sell. Myrna has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos a month from these activities. In 2009, Myrna joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Myrna is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. This will be the first loan taken out by Myrna from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future

loans.name: Danilon Marina

texts.en:
Danilon Marina L. is from the village of Libag Sur, Tuguegarao City. She is 34 years old and married with three school-aged children. To make a living, Danilon Marina raises pigs for sale. Danilon Marina has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately $68 a month from this activity.

In 2008, Danilon Marina joined the Kiva field partner, ASKI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation by engaging in business activities. Danilon Marina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI. She is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be her 4th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Estela

texts.en: Estela C. is from the village of Hinaplanon, Iligan City. She is 41 years old, is widowed, and has five school-aged children. Estela owns and operates a business making and selling food, selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Estela joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Estela is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 2nd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Negielyn's Group

texts.en:
Negielyn V. is 33 years old and from the village of Remus, Baggao, Cagayan. She is the group leader of a six-member group loan offered by Kiva partner, ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.
Negielyn is married and has three infant-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a service-based business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing repair services to local community members. Negielyn has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month from these activities.
In 2010, Negielyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be her first from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business.

About ASKI
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Chea

texts.en: Chea P., age 26, is married and resides with her husband in Takeo Province, Cambodia. She has a child. She is a construction worker, earning approximately US $3 per day. By doing so, she is able to cover her family's expenses, especially those for her children’s education. She has been doing this business since 2009. Her husband is a construction foreman, earning an income of US $7 per day. Their standard of living has improved since P.’s husband has been doing this business, so she wants to have a loan to expand his business. P. is requesting a loan of US $800 to buy more construction tools to expand his business. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a partner of Kiva.

loans.use: To buy construction tools

loans.name: Yesenia Maria

texts.es: La Joven Yesenia Maria tiene 28años, es una mujer muy responsable y luchadora, su actividad económica es la venta de ropa nueva, ella tiene 2 hijos de los cuales tiene que velar y mantener. Por lo que inicio hace más de 5 años y fue porque desde muy joven le gustaba ganarse la vida, por lo que tiene que dejar su casa a las 5 de la mañana para estar en las afueras de las calles recibiendo el fuerte sol, pues el único medio de protección que tiene es una chaqueta así ofrece sus productos. Ella solicita este financiamiento para capital de trabajo que será destinado para la compra de ropa interior, calcetines, camisolas y camisetas. Su deseo es obtener otra fuente de ingreso para mejorar su condición económica.
texts.en:
Yesenia Maria is 28 years-old and has two children for whom she is responsible. She sells new clothes, a job she started 5 years ago because of her strong desire to earn a living. She leaves her house every morning at 5a to sell her products (she only has a jacket to keep her warm). She requests this loan to purchase additional merchandise, specifically underwear, socks, and shirts. She also hopes to obtain another source of income so she can improve her economic condition.

Translated from Spanish by Jim Muir, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase additional merchandise: underwear, socks, shirts

loans.name: Maurino

texts.es:
Maurino tiene 60 años, es casado y tiene 16 hijos. Vive en la localidad de “Quimbiri”, zona de ceja de selva, donde tienen su casa propia.

Su familia se dedicaba a la carpintería, específicamente a fabricar muebles, es por ello que desde muy joven ha quedado grabado en su memoria el sonido de las máquinas y el olor de la madera. Actualmente está dedicado de lleno a la misma actividad, durante casi 38 años, trabajando desde las 6 de la mañana hasta las 8 de la noche. A Maurino le gusta mucho su trabajo, ya que le proporciona buenos resultados económicos. Él elabora muebles tradicionales y contemporáneos, pues sabe que la diversificación es la clave de las buenas ventas. Para el futuro, espera ampliar el espacio donde trabaja, para almacenar su materia prima, los artículos acabados y comprar nuevas máquinas.

Este es su tercer préstamo con MFP y se compromete a seguir cumpliendo con su cronograma de pagos de manera puntual, además se siente contento con la solidaridad de su banco comunal. Con el dinero solicitado adquirirá más madera (cedro, caoba y tornillo) con la finalidad de cumplir con sus compromisos.
texts.en:
Maurino is 60 years old, married, and has 16 children. He lives in the town of Quimbiri on the edge of the jungle, where he has his own house.

His family works in the carpentry business, specifically making furniture. This is why since he was young, the sound of the machines and the smell of the wood has been etched in his memory. He is has been in the same business for almost 38 years and works from 6am to 8pm. Maurino likes his job very much, since it provides him with good earnings. He makes traditional and contemporary furniture and he knows that diversification is the key to good sales. In the future, he hopes to expand the space in which he works to store his raw material, finished work, and to purchase new machines.

This is his third loan with MFP and he promises to continue making his scheduled payments on time. In addition, he is happy with the solidarity of his communal bank. With the requested loan, he will purchase more wood (cedar, mahogany, tornillo) with the purpose of fulfilling his commitments.

Translated from Spanish by Kathleen O'Connell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase wood

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora is a 30-year-old lady who has been selling tomatoes, onions, and fruit for two years in a very competitive environment.  Since she became a member of Faulu Kenya, she has been motivated to work hard in her business.  She belongs to a group called Diamond Women within Faulu Kenya, which has guaranteed her a loan of KES 20,000.  

Flora is a hardworking and visionary lady who hopes to enlarge her business so as to become financially stable.  She plans to use this loan to buy more tomatoes and onions for sale.

loans.use: To buy tomatoes and onions for resale

loans.name: María Flor Bertila

texts.es:
María Flor tiene 42 años de edad, es casada y tiene 5 hijos, dos de los cuales son menores de edad, vive junto a su familia en el caserío Sequiones, una zona rural del distrito de Mórrope, conocido a niver regional por tener a la mayoría de su población concentrada en áreas rurales que distan mucho una de la otra, la mayoria de su población es considerada como pobre, pertenece a la provincia de Lambayeque y se encuentra ubicada a a hora y  media de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Se dedica desde hace mas de 12 años a la crianza y venta de animales. Ella cría cerdos, chivos y aves de corral en la parte posterior de su vivienda, cuando estos han alcanzado un buen punto de desarrollo, los ofrece en venta a los negociantes que frecuentemente están visitando la zona para adquirir animales  menores y revenderlos en la ciudad de Chiclayo. Como este negocio ella ayuda a su esposo en el sostenimiento de su hogar.

Adicionalmente María Flor se dedica a la comercialización de leña y carbón, su esposo extrae el combustible de los bosques secos de la zona y ella los vende a sus vecinos, estos combustibles tienen bastante acogida en la zona ya que son utilizados para la elaboración de alimentos.

María Flor desea ampliar su negocio con la compra de mas cerdos y de alimento balanceado para desarrollarlos bien y así obtener mas ingresos, por ello ha decidido solicitar a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 2000 nuevos soles que le ayuden a lograr su objetivo.

María Flor es es una mujer bastante hogareña y que siempre vela por el bienestar de su familia. Ella ya trabajado anteriormente con Nuestra Institución y ha demostrado puntualidad y responsabilidad al momento de asumir sus pagos.
texts.en:
María Flor is 42 years old, married and has five children, two who are still minors. She lives with her family in the hamlet of Sequiones in a rural zone in the district of Mórrope that is known for having the majority of its population concentrated in rural areas very far from one another. The majority of the population is considered poor, comes from the province of Lambayeque and is about an hour and a half from the city of Chiclayo. María makes a living raising and selling animals. She raises pigs, goats and poultry in her home's backyard. When those animals reach a good point in their development, she puts them up for sell to the businesses that frequently visit the area to acquire animals to then resell in Chiclayo. This business helps María's husband cover household expenses. Additionally, María also sells firewood and charcoal. Her husband extracts the wood from the dry forests in the area and she sells it to their neighbors. The firewood is well-received since the people used to make their meals. María wishes to expand her business by purchasing more pigs and feed to promote a good development and thus increase her income. She has decided to request a loan from Kiva partner Edpyme Alternativa of 2000 soles that will help her achieve this objective. María is a home-loving woman who always watches out for her family's well being. She has worked int he past with Edpyme Alternativa and has shown herself to be punctual and responsible with her payments.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase pigs and feeds to expand her business

loans.name: Lidia Estela

texts.es:
La Srta.Lidia Estela Velasquez Nunez es soltera hija única de padres Separados, vive con su madre y se halla cursando el 4to año de una carrera universitaria.
 La clienta inicio sus actividades comerciales para poder hacer frente a los gastos que conllevan los estudios y ayudar a su madre. 
Inicio creando en su casa y para sus amigos y conocidos accesorios y bijuterìa como ser collares, aros pulseras, bordado de vestidos de fiestas con canutillos y lentejuelas, la publicidad se fue haciendo de boca en boca por lo que ella habilito un pequeño show room en la sala de su domicilioparticular lo cual le resulto muy exitoso y recibía diariamente múltiples visitas y pedidos por lo que hoy después de 2 años de seguir con el negocio decidió, además de los accesorios de su creación vender prendas de vestir para damas y otras cosas como carteras y calzados, con el crédito otorgado por la Fundación Paraguaya la misma realizaría la apertura formal de su tienda.
texts.en:
Miss Lidia Estela Velasquez Nunez is the only child of her separated parents. She lives with her mother, and is currently in her fourth year of her degree program at the university. This client began her business to be able to cover the costs involved in studying and trying to help out her mother with household expenses at the same time. She began by making jewelry and accessories for her friends at home, like necklaces, earrings, bracelets, and embellishing party dresses. Word of mouth garnered her a lot of attention, so she now has a little showroom in her room, which is very successful, and she has multiple visits and orders each day. After two years of this, she has decided to, along with her accessories, to sell articles of clothing for women, as well as purses and shoes. With the loan provided by Fundación Paraguaya, she will formally open her boutique.

Translated from Spanish by Shaun Haines, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of handbags, shoes, and clothing for women

loans.name: Celia

texts.en: Celia L. is a 40-year-old married woman who lives in Purok 3 Alim, Hinoba-an, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by buying and selling rice and also by a motorcycle transport and farming businesses. Celia’s husband, Carlito, is a driver and farmer and they have five children: one is already married and four are single. Celia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon (NWTF-PD ) in 2002 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD she has been able to increase their family income through her various business activities which now earns her an average monthly income of Php 10,000. Celia is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of Php 21,000 was used to fund operations of her rice sales and farming businesses and it had a positive impact on both the businesses and on the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing Php 23,000 for her 10th loan which she intends to add to the operating capital of her businesses. Celia is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which are to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To use as additional working capital for her businesses

loans.name: Ayisietu

texts.en: Ayisietu A. prepares kenkey for sale and also sells oranges in Abura. The type of kenkey she prepares is commonly called “Ga kenkey". It is prepared and eaten by the Ga people in the Greater Accra region. As the Fante have Fante kenkey; so the Ga have Ga kenkey. The difference between the two is that corn husk is used for wrapping, whilst plantain leaves are used to wrap Fante kenkey, but the method of preparation is the same. Ayisietu has received senior high education. She is married and her husband is a mobile phone repairman. She helps her husband to take care of the home. Her loan will be used to buy more maize to prepare kenkey for sale and a greater variety of fruits, including oranges, to sell. She hopes to save the new profits from her business to roof the place where she sells.

loans.use: To buy more maize to prepare kenkey for sale and fruit, including oranges

loans.name: Mrs. Sophoan Muong Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophoan Muong is a village bank president who has been selected by the ten group members who all live in Trapeang Ta Eak village in Kampong Speu province. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice. They have taken out a loan as part of AMK’s loan workout program. Each client has an outstanding loan with AMK that they are unable to repay. 


Mrs. Sophoan Muong has three children: one is a taxi driver, the second child is employed in a garment factory and the youngest child is attending school. Her husband is a taxi diver who makes a small income to support the family.

As part of AMK’s workout program, each client is trained to produce a product. The ten members of Sophoan Muong’s group have been trained to produce papers. They have been given a loan to purchase raw material and equipment to create papers, while AMK provides them with materials to produce the goods. Ahkun.org will purchase the goods from the clients and sell them on their website. Profits from the sale will go to the group to further help them pay off their outstanding loans, and the loans of their fellow villagers who are in the same difficult position.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials and equipment to create papers.
